B000024D4R|5.0|I think \\"floydians\\" will agree with me that if they had to pinpoint one Floyd album as being pure genius, ANIMALS would be on top of the list. DSOTM and WYWH are examples of flawless music, great production, brilliant songwriting and near-perfect lyrics but I think Animals just about beats the other two in the \\"genius\\" category.DSOTM and WYWH were groundbreaking albums and I absolutely love those albums (Hey, I love anything by PF ! ), but there is something about Animals for which I keep going back to it again and again.<br /><br />I think the reason for it is David Gilmour. Yes, I know Roger Waters wrote the lyrics and the concept was entirely his (BTW the concept of Animals did not come about until the end of the studio recordings), but it is Dave who steals the show with his angry guitar playing, consistent with the mood of the problem.The band (sans waters) was obviously not pleased with Waters increasing hegemony over the band, especially when it came to songwriting.  Nick Mason has said during an interview that by this time Roger thought that he could be PINK FLOYD and do everything by himself (The final Cut !!). I think Dave stood up to the \\"injustice ?\\" with the only way he knows best, by belting rocking solos in \\"Dogs\\" and \\"Sheep\\". That was Daves way of saying that PF were not a finished group regardless of the power struggle in the band. Anything from Rick Wright was vetoed and Dave himself got just one credit for his stellar show. But I think this is one of the reasons why Animals rocks as you can feel the animosity in their music. Was \\"Sheep\\" indirectly aimed at the other members of the group ? The \\"Sheeps\\" obvioulsy being the rest of the group while the Roger is both a \\"Pig\\" as well as the \\"Dog\\". Whatever the reason, the resulting chemistry or rather the lack of it gives Animals that much more of a personal touch to it. One has to commend PF for atleast putting aside their differences  and coming up with this absolute rocker of a album.
B000683VI4|4.0|I read some reviews that paint The Notebook in a bad light, but I liked it. It was a touching film, well written, well acted and directed, and in my opinion the actors were perfectly cast for their parts.  <br /> <br />The Notebook tells the tale of a summer love that stands the test of time. In a retirement home nestled along a picturesque southern river bank, an old gentleman, \\"Duke\\" (Garner), reads regularly to a charming elderly woman (Rowlands), who suffers memory loss and confusion due to dimentia. He reads to her from a book that tells the story of a young couple (Gosling, McAdams) who were drawn together during a summer of love in a small southern town. This love proves to hold strong even through separation and the impending marriage of the young lady to another man.  <br /> <br />My wife and I actually cried at the end. Call me shallow, but The Notebook puts things into perspective for those in a relationship. It reminds us how important love is, how special life is, and how we need to make the most of things and focus on life and really living it

B0000028M7|5.0|I've been a fan of Alice In Chains for about 5 years now. I'm only sorry I discovered them so late (well, I only got into Grunge, Metal and Alternative when I turned 13). I got this album after hearing their \\"Greatest Hits\\" and seeing \\"Them Bones\\" on T.V. And all I can say about this album is - brutal, sorrowful, incredible, satisfying genius! I'm going to review each song for you so you can get a complete view of the album as it is - and if you'd rather not read the review, at least read the end: I'll give you guys a few Alice In Chains Rareties Titles that you can download if you don't have them. As far as I know they're not on any recorded albums - so I'll be happy to share the tracks with you. Anyway, here's the low down on Alice In Chains' \\"Dirt.\\"<br /><br />\\"Them Bones\\" kicks the album off and is an extremely angry, bitter song that reeks of self-loathing and confusion. The song basically comments on how we will all die one day and how it is an inescapable inevitability. It also plays on the folk-song titled \\"Them Bones.\\" It's a great, succinct, direct and hard-hitting song. It's not my absolute favourite, but it's definitely way up there with my best. It gets 10/10, no doubt.<br /><br />\\"Dam That River\\" is another heavy and rather short song. But in my opinion it's even better than \\"Them Bones.\\" It's just got some killer guitar work and nicely interspersed lead bits. It's slightly more complex than \\"Them Bones\\" and also uses metaphors of a River flooding to explain an incident that occured between Jerry Cantrell and Shaun Kinney. According to Mike Starr's Biography \\"Unchained\\" (which I'm currently reading - it's pretty funny and is actually a biography of the whole band in essence) Jerry was pi$$ing off Sean and so Sean proceeded to break a coffee table over the arrogant guitarist's head. This caused Jerry to move out of the band's communal house and in with Eddie Vedder. He focused his anger for Sean into this very song. The reason this song is so great is because it has a really interesting if somewhat strange backstory, and is just well structured and written. \\"Dam That River\\" gets 11/10 in my book!<br /><br />\\"Rain When I Die\\" is a rather macabre song that starts off with an almost sluggish bassline and Cantrell's signature Wah-Wah stylings. The vocals then kick in with a kind of climactic wailing and then moves into a Wah-Wah driven riff. The song is rather slow and seems to be talking about the end of a long relationship (hey, these songs are everywhere!). I must admit that it isn't my best, but I consider it to be a great song. Track 3 gets 9/10 I think.<br /><br />\\"Down In A Hole\\" is a really sad and sorrowful song. The verse riff is driven by a Chorus/Phaser effect and Layne's vocals are soulful and penetrating. The song seems to be talking about being alone and depressed. Perhaps it even speaks about how those bred for success often \\"fail\\" in a sense. This song grew on me after a few listens and is pretty saddening. The lyrics are intelligent and meaningful and it's a really wonderful song. \\"Down In A Hole\\" gets 9.5/10.<br /><br />\\"Sickman\\" starts off with drums and then the guitar starts up soon thereafter. This song talks about confusion and about being sick, delerious and depressed. The song is pretty strange and is oddly structured. It certainly makes you feel pretty weird and almost like you're in your own world I guess. I like this song but I consider it to be just good. I give \\"Sickman\\" 8/10. It's just not that memorable, but it's a good listen nonetheless.<br /><br />\\"Rooster\\" is a classic A.I.C song. The song is about Jerry Cantrell's father who served in the Vietnam War. He was known as \\"The Rooster\\" and so this is a very personal song for Jerry. It's sad, haunting, deep and simply classic. If you're by yourself at night and lying on the bed, you may just cry when you hear this song. It's just that incredible, and for many A.I.C fans, they already know that. 10.5/10 for \\"Rooster.\\"<br /><br />\\"Junkhead\\" is a pretty heavy song with a great chorus. It talks about Drug use and how the band members would often do anything to get pills, needles and weed. The song is pretty angry and has an element of regret in it - clearly the band members all feel ashamed of their actions, but at the same time they also seem to explain why they did the things they did. You'll almost always sing along to \\"What's my drug of choice?...Well what have you got?\\" It's a damn good track and earns 9.5/10 from my side. Also be sure to listen to the solo, it's really cool!<br /><br />\\"Dirt\\" starts off with a lead bit supported by Kinney on cymbals. The song is medium paced and talks about the after effects of taking drugs and being alone, angry and regretful. As you can see, this album has a sense of time (an example of this is the previous songs \\"Sickman\\" and \\"Junkhead) as we see the illness, the feelings and desire for drugs, and then the after effects of drug use. The song has a great solo and is also filled with self-loathing and sadness. The riff is just fantastic, and the lyrics really reflect the feelings of Staley and the band with great effect. This song gets 10/10 in my opinion.<br /><br />\\"God Smack\\" has a great riff and some really freaky vocal work. Another idiot reviewer said that A.I.C were ripping off \\"Godsmack.\\" What this empty-headed fool doesn't realise is that \\"Godsmack\\" came years after A.I.C and took their name from this song! If I could, I would find that person and kick the $#!t out of him. Or her. Anyway, this song is angry and once again continues with the drug use theme and how things got progressively worse in the band. Layne sounds great on this track and really delivers and extremely unique vocal performance and all the other band members carry off their parts excellently. \\"God Smack\\" gets 9/10.<br /><br />\\"Intro (Dream Sequence),\\" also known as \\"Iron Gland\\" is just an interlude and is just pretty freaky. Not a song really, so there's no need to rate this little piece.<br /><br />\\"Hate To Feel\\" begins with Cantrell's guitar and then Kinney and Staley coming in soon thereafter. The song is pretty slow and talks about the recovery from drug use and how it is a slow and painful process. The song is angry and apocalyptic and speaks volumes of how ex-drug users withdraw into themselves and feel awful from withdrawal symptons. The song's great but is by no means a classic. It scores 8.5/10 over here.<br /><br />\\"Angry Chair\\" is a really umm...angry and tense song. This track seems to be talking about what it's like to be grounded as a child or taking time out, but seems to look at the psychological effects on a kid. There again it could be talking about what it's like to be alone and confused and not really understanding why. The drums are awesome in this song, as is the guitar riff. Layne penetrates deeply and really dishes out an emotional whirlwind for the listener. It's just a fantastic song and the video always creeps me out! 10.5/10 for \\"Angry Chair.\\"<br /><br />And now, the closer, \\"Would?\\" Man do I love this song. It's probably my favourite song by the band. Every time I listen to the opening bassline I can just feel the shivers down my spine. The song is ghostly and is unintrusive in some respects. The lyrics are phenomenal and always remind me of a fallout I had with some of my friends 2 and a half years ago. The lyrics talk about making a mistake and how your friends won't forgive you. I almost cry when it gets to the end of the song, it's simply haunting. And when Layne says \\"left you here alone!\\" I just feel so incredibly regretful. It's a song that helped me through many days of loneliness and confusion, and I know that it'll be meaningful to you too. \\"Would?\\" gets an undeniable 11/10! Don't even argue with me on that one!<br /><br />Overall, I'd give this CD 93%. It's just an amazing experience and I've got to give all the band members huge credit. Every one made it personal, unique and just totally incredible. If you love A.I.C, you had better own this CD! It's simply brilliant! Just buy it today, you won't regret it at all!<br /><br />Now for those songs I promised. Search for the following song titles by Alice In Chains:<br /><br />1) \\"Blue\\" - this is an acoustic song by the band but is really beautiful. I totally love this song! Find it quickly!<br /><br />2) \\"Foolish\\" - Another beautiful song but is way more electric. Find it, it's fantastic! And the chorus - WOAH! Amazing!<br /><br />3) \\"Another Brick In The Wall\\" - A Pink Floyd Cover that's pretty funky and really slick. Check it out!<br /><br />4) \\"Heroin\\" - A faster version of \\"Real Thing\\" from the album \\"Facelift.\\" I prefer this version because it's just got more of a bite! Really fantastic!<br /><br />5) \\"Alone\\" - A song with Pearl Jam. It's an acoustic song but is worthy of great acclaim! It's a really great rare song, trust me!<br /><br />And those are the rareties that I've found so far. I'm not aware of their existence on other CD's or whatever, but if they do, I want those CDs! Anyway, I hope this has all been useful. Keep listening to Alice In Chains and may Layne Staley Rest In Peace always...to rate this little piece. <br /> <br />\\"Hate To Feel\\" begins with Cantrell's guitar and then Kinney and Staley coming in soon thereafter. The song is pretty slow and talks about the recovery from drug use and how it is a slow and painful process. The song is angry and apocalyptic and speaks volumes of how ex-drug users withdraw into themselves and feel awful from withdrawal symptons. The song's great but is by no means a classic. It scores 8.5/10 over here. <br /> <br />\\"Angry Chair\\" is a really umm...angry and tense song. This track seems to be talking about what it's like to be grounded as a child or taking time out, but seems to look at the psychological effects on a kid. There again it could be talking about what it's like to be alone and confused and not really understanding why. The drums are awesome in this song, as is the guitar riff. Layne penetrates deeply and really dishes out an emotional whirlwind for the listener. It's just a fantastic song and the video always creeps me out! 10.5/10 for \\"Angry Chair.\\" <br /> <br />And now, the closer, \\"Would?\\" Man do I love this song. It's probably my favourite song by the band. Every time I listen to the opening bassline I can just feel the shivers down my spine. The song is ghostly and is unintrusive in some respects. The lyrics are phenomenal and always remind me of a fallout I had with some of my friends 2 and a half years ago. The lyrics talk about making a mistake and how your friends won't forgive you. I almost cry when it gets to the end of the song, it's simply haunting. And when Layne says \\"left you here alone!\\" I just feel so incredibly regretful. It's a song that helped me through many days of loneliness and confusion, and I know that it'll be meaningful to you too. \\"Would?\\" gets an undeniable 11/10! Don't even argue with me on that one! <br /> <br />Overall, I'd give this CD 93%. It's just an amazing experience and I've got to give all the band members huge credit. Every one made it personal, unique andjust totally incredible. If you love A.I.C, you had better own this CD! It's simply brilliant! Just buy it today, you won't regret it at all! <br /> <br />Now for those songs I promised. Search for the following song titles by Alice In Chains: <br /> <br />1) \\"Blue\\" - this is an acoustic song by the band but is really beautiful. I totally love this song! Find it quickly! <br /> <br />2) \\"Foolish\\" - Another beautiful song but is way more electric. Find it, it's fantastic! And the chorus - WOAH! Amazing! <br /> <br />3) \\"Another Brick In The Wall\\" - A Pink Floyd Cover that's pretty funky and really slick. Check it out! <br /> <br />4) \\"Heroin\\" - A faster version of \\"Real Thing\\" from the album \\"Facelift.\\" I prefer this version because it's just got more of a bite! Really fantastic! <br /> <br />5) \\"Alone\\" - A song with Pearl Jam. It's an acoustic song but is worthy of great acclaim! It's a really great rare song, trust me! <br /> <br />And those are the rareties that I've found so far. I'm not aware of their existence on other CD's or whatever, but if they do, I want those CDs! Anyway, I hope this has all been useful. Keep listening to Alice In Chains and may Layne Staley Rest In Peace always...
B000B8QEZG|4.0|Let's be honest. 2005 was a rather bland year in music. Sure,we had bands like Franz Ferdinand, The Killers, Coldplay, and Foo Fighters churning out hits left and right. Aside from the up and coming machine beats of M.I.A., the so-so Black Eyed Peas and Gwen Stefani's smorgasboard of glossy styles, we really didn't have much else in the way of funky.Well I guess we had to wait until November. Now who would have thought that our Madonna, who had been getting more attention for her political views and religion (which some say is just another gold tooth or nose ring)than her actual music, would release one of the year's most notable records? When we last heard her in our players, it was on 2003's American Life, which felt a bit undercooked. Where on that record, she seemed to have traded her signature genre-crossing sound with the \\"electro-folk\\" that powered her Ray Of Light and Music albums. But in the case of American Life, that secret recipe had already expired. What's a girl to do? Why, hit the dance floor of course. And this being Madge, it comes so naturally. Anyone who was worried prior to the release about a full on dance record need not worry. On 'Confessions', Madonna parties like it's 1985. Or 1975. Or whatever. It's that attitude that gives the record it's spark. Madonna promises it will be okay, just shake your booty and the rest will follow. It's almost eerie to stand back and listen to Madonna doing all this, not that we doubted she could. But ITS JUST THAT GOOD. The songs all blend nicely together like a non stop DJ mix, and it's a good bet that this is the best party you'll attend in your living room all year. Kicking off with the ABBA-coated first single \\"Hung Up\\", it's infectious pop at its finest through the exquisite \\"Get Together\\" and the supposed second single \\"Sorry\\", which centers around a fed up Madonna saying \\"I've heard it all before\\". That's what makes 'Confessions' so brilliant in it's simplicity. Even at it's most chilled out, Madonna seems warm and vibrant again for the first time since 1998's Ray Of Light. And while there is not much in the way of \\"confessions\\" here and the emotional meat of Ray of Light and some of Music is absent, some of the album's declarations about independence (\\"Jump\\", \\"Sorry\\")and survival (\\"Let it Will Be\\", \\"Like it or Not\\") hold their own, as such themes did on albums such as Erotica and Bedtime Stories. But where those 90's albums (except for Ray of Light) often lacked sonically, 'Confessions' straightens Madonna's crown as the queen of dance music. The album never claimed to be end all for songwriting; I say this because I know critics will pan some of the lyrics. The best example is the dippy \\"I Love New York\\", which rhymes 'York' with dork, chooses to say \\"F-off\\" rather than just come out and say it, and then rhymes that with 'golf'. Yikes. Shouldn't New York deserve better than that? Still despite these and other minor flaws, we could be faced with another rap about soy lattes. The focal point here is dance, dance, dance. With a variety of samples, her own wizardry with producer Stuart Price, and the nostalgia for the nightlife Madonna has successfully reclaimed her throne. Standouts: Get Together, Sorry, Let it Will Be, Jump, and Isaac.

B000B5UL7G|4.0|No longer collaborating with the esteemed & very able Guy Chambers, Robbie's new collaborator, Stephen Duffy either fails to engage, or he just isn't really trying. Right up front, it should be made clear, that I really want Robbie to make it at least half as well in America as he has in the UK. Not so sure that this is the album that will do it, but hope floats, doesn't it?  <br /> <br />While Life Thru a Lens was as powerful as a racehorse sprinting to the virtual finish, leaving I've Been Expecting You a satisfying, if only slightly pedestrian sophomore effort. All bets were paid off with the stellar, perfect Sing When You're Winning, leaving Escapology a very close second. Swing When You're Winning & Live at Knebworth remain his pinnacle releases, but seeing as the former was [almost entirely] an excellent \\"covers with friends\\" effort & the latter, while a riveting live effort, not since Frampton has a live album really taken the prize, especially if never official released stateside. In order to crack the U.S. market, he needs to really show in the studio.  <br /> <br />Intensive Care is at first so seemingly mellow, almost too \\"pop/bubblegum\\" radio-friendly, as to be off-putting. \\"Ghosts\\" is an excellent opener, partnered effectively with the faux-reggae \\"Tripping\\" for a respectable one-two punch. The next two, \\"Make Me Pure\\" & \\"Spread Your Wings\\" immediately squander all that the opening pair promised. \\"Advertising Space\\" brings things back into near-focus, but the name-dropping [Brando, Watergate, Vietnam] leave a lot to be desired. \\"Please Don't Die\\" nearly feels like another \\"Angels,\\" but not quite. At this point, there is clearly need for another punch. \\"Your Gay Friend\\" delivers, blasting along with full-on rock intensity; back, too, is the marvelous Robbie sense of humor, wordplay and those oh-so-titillating possibilities that he might just swing. Sameness prevails on the boorish Sin Sin Sin & The Trouble With Me, which both sound phoned in. Random Actsof Kindness takes on an almost Sgt Pepper/Magical Mystery Tour feel; especially love the gut-bucket harmonica. With its prevailing peace on earth, good will lyric & feel, this could easily replace what \\"Angels\\" has been for some. \\"A Place to Crash\\" invites back the kick-butt rocker. Leaving \\"King of Bloke & Bird\\" to close on an elegant, if somewhat awkward tone, especially the final, haunting, ethereal chord at the closing, which seems almost to tease that maybe, just maybe, there might be something more. \\"Summer me on to another day...\\" indeed.  <br /> <br />Still, Robbie far transcends any male pop star that the U.S. has tried to market to the masses. Even if we would have liked a little more earnestness & originality, in the long run, Robbie is worth having even if the transition with Duffy is, at least at this point, a tad wanting.  <br />

B0001CCXY8|5.0|\\"The Wretched Spawn,\\" Cannibal Corpse's sixth album without original frontman Chris Barnes, is one of the better death metal albums of 2004, and probably CC's best release since Barnes left the group. George Fisher, the new vocalist, is very deep and gruff, but his vocals aren't monstrous. Plus, George does change speed (as in tracks one and two), but he doesn't change pitch; there are almost no shrieks or high pitched yells, on here. Other than that, though, this record has everything you need for great death metal: huge riffs, rapid fire drums, propulsive tempos, speaker vibrating rhythms, disgusting lyrics, etc. Even an occasional solo flares up from time to time. \\"Psychotic Precision\\" has surging, grinding riffs, jackhammer drums, and two solos. The title track slows down and becomes an almost bobbing beat, but then a scorching solo kicks in and speeds the pace back up. \\"Cyanide Assassin\\" begins with a fast, steam rolling beat, but it slows down and some super heavy, churning riffs take over. \\"Festering in the Crypt\\" is a mid-paced rocker which gains momentum with cascading riffs and a high pitched yell. \\"Nothing Left to Mutilate\\" features a pounding rhythm, with dizzying, circular riffs and fast double bass drumming. \\"Rotted Body Landslide\\" sounds like the drummer, Paul, is cracking his snare drum, and \\"Slain\\" has more fast, buzzsaw riffs. If you're new to Cannibal Corpse, or if you like growls more than monstrous vocals, \\"The Wretched Spawn\\" is a good place to start. And if you like death metal, nothing should prevent you from picking up this album.

B000065BPB|4.0|Most of my friends had never heard of Sennheiser.  A few even told me, that I should've bought a Bose, since I spent USD One hundred on these Sennheisers.  Bose's triport headphones were my first choice too (since I didn't know any better then).  After seeing the flimsy band, which looked eager to snap in half, I returned them, and got the Sennheisers. <br /> <br />They're heavier than the Bose Triport, but after a few minutes of wearing them, you get so used to them, that they feel quite natural.  The ear cups are soft and supple, that it really pads the skin from any rough feeling.  It feels awesome to wear for several hours at a stretch.  I use it for hours while programming away at work.  It cancels outside noise by a lot, even with the passive cancellation - its that well insulated.  Turn the music on, and even at low volumes, you're well isolated from your environment - its all crystal clear music. <br /> <br />The crystal-clear highs and mids, make me listen to all my old CD's and iTunes MP3s over and over.  The only complaint I have, is that bass is not this pair of headphones' strong points.  Bass is controlled and for songs such as Hotel California (Eagles) and Fast Car (Tracy Chapman), the sound is amazing, very tight bass and crystal clear bass.  But, for any kind of hip-hop or other bass-heavy music, this is not the headphones for you.  Since I only very rarely listen to hip-hop, I don't find this bothering at all.   <br /> <br />In short, this is one heck of a good deal - great style, awesome build, comfort, clarity and substance.  I took off 1 star for the lacklustre bass performance.

0684824906|5.0|Lincoln is arguably amongest the most heavily written American presidents and rightfully so.  He brought a silent and profound manner of dealing with national political calamaities that perhaps only Franklyn Delano Roosevelt was able to replicate admirably some 100 years later.  Mrs Goodwins approach and writing style are a composite mix between Chernow (Alexander Hamilton) and McCullough's (1776 and John Adams).  Her insight adds an admirable dimension to President Lincoln that I was not prevy to prior to reading this biography.  For example, Lincoln had a foundness during his presidency for Euclidean geometry having read and performed exercises on books 1-6.  Lincoln's demeanor often conflicted with his  personal outside appearance (appearing sad, depressed but then a moment later would tell spellbindinng joke often with a lesson to be learned.  Lincoln was also very patient always with a constructive motive.  Example, his Secretary of the Treasury-Chase  entertained the strong desires of becoming President and inflicted upon Lincoln often severe open criticisms to the public.  These criticisms were vicious and many times exaggerated  only to grace a better appearance for Chase.  This was consummated with Chase resignation delivered on four seperate occassions with all four times Chase assuming he was too important to be allowed to leave Lincoln's cabinet.  But finally his welcome was outgrown its usefulness and Licoln unexpectantly allowed him to leave the administration. However, Lincoln respected his judicial prudence and several months later made him Chief Justice of the  Supreme Court.  Such a fortunate reversal of opportunity would not occur in America in 2005.  But all the nuances of his decision making are properly captured and presented in enlightening detail and prose.  Additionally, at the time of Lincoln assasination I was unaware of the almost successful attempt on the same day with the life of Seward (Secretary of State) and Sewards son, Fred.  Additionally,  three months prior to the end of the Civil War, Lincoln met with Stephen Davis(President of the Confederate States)  to potentiallly end the conflict with what has been called the Hampton  Road's Conference.  This was unsuccessful because Davis was unwilling to allow the conflict to resolve with the South rejoining the union become one United States.  Less than two months later Grant received the unconditional surrender of the South and Davis had then no input. B00005JNX0|4.0|\\"Madagascar\\", like most of the Dreamworks animated movies, is a kitchen-sink hodgepodge. The good news is that this hodgepodge is better than anything I've seen from this outfit, and that includes both \\"Shreks\\". Kids will love these truly funny animals, while their moms and dads will get a boot out of bits that spoof everything from \\"Seinfeld\\" (a major influence on this movie) to \\"The Twilight Zone\\". <br />        The first section of \\"Madagascar\\" is set in New York City, where the four \\"zoosters\\"- Alex the lion (voice of Ben Stiller), Marty the zebra (Chris Rock), Gloria the hippo (Jada Pinkett-Smith), and my favorite, Melman the giraffe (David Schwimmer)- are the stars of the Central Park zoo and pampered beyond belief after the kids go home. One day, Marty decides to escape the zoo and take the train to the wilds of Connecticut. Ever see a zebra in Times Square? A giraffe on the subway? A lion emerging onto the concourse at Grand Central? Some clever animation brings old-time \\"Looney Tunes\\" tricks to the computer era as our heroes, cornered by a hundred of New York's finest, wind up in crates on a freighter, Kenya-bound. Soon, the Four Penguins- the unsung stars of this movie- start one of their wiseguy capers and hijack the ship. The four crates fall off the boat and, \\"Survivor\\"-style, wash up on the beaches of what they assume to be the San Diego Zoo- but it's really the huge island of Madagascar, where they interact with a merry band of lemurs led by goofy dancing King Julian (Sacha Baron Cohen, aka \\"Ali G\\") <br />and his skunk-like sidekick Maurice (Cedric the Entertainer).  <br />       That's the story, such as it is. The movie, however, doesn't have the well-defined characters and themes that, in my mind, Pixar will always do best. What it does have is a dizzying array of slapstick gags, a \\"Friends\\"/\\"Seinfeld\\" dialogue rhythm (at least in the NYC portion), quickie skits that touch on old TV shows (Marty surfs onto the beach to the strains of the \\"Hawaii Five-0\\" theme) and other movies (Alex talks to a soccer ball, \\"Cast Away\\"-style), and similar touches that will definitely tickle your funny bone. More than almost any computer- <br />animated movie I've seen, \\"Madagascar\\" tries- and largely succeeds- to create what its crew calls \\"more cartoon-y gags and characters\\". <br />         A good array of extra features include not only interviews with the voice cast and director/writers, but a look at the \\"stretch\\" effects that, in the words of one animator, are <br />\\"very difficult with computers\\". They're especially good on anything involving Melman, the lovably-neurotic, pill-popping giraffe. The best extra, however, is \\"The Penguins' Christmas Caper\\", which brings the four birds front and center in a very funny holiday tale. Tom McGrath, the \\"Madagascar\\" co-director and writer, also voices the penguins' leader with a very amusing New York cop-style sneer. Musical selections could be a little better- veteran Hans Zimmer's best contribution is a pulsing lion-show theme for Alex- but the use of pop/theme cues does get a little heavy-handed. I loved the penguin short's music, though: <br />two nifty \\"Jingle Bells\\" takeoffs by Brian Setzer (swing-a-billy) <br />and the Brave Combo (klezmer-ized!). As for the voices, Stiller can be overbearing and smug, while Rock seems to be a little tentative. But Schwimmer, having played a sub-Woody Allen role on \\"Friends\\" for ten years, has his lovable-mope bit down pat. Baron Cohen's peculiar Euro-Indian accent can grate, but I loved his greeting to the American visitors: \\"Hail the New York Giants!\\" Finally, there's a look at the real Madagascar and how the filmmakers replicated some of this distant island nation's one-of-a-kind fauna and flora. (Incidentally, you couldn't see \\"Madagascar\\" on Madagascar- its capital city has a million people and only one movie house!) <br />         \\"Madagascar\\" may be a Dreamworks pastiche, but it's a pretty good one. Animation buffs, New Yorkcomedy fans, and kids who love funny animal characters will all find something to laugh at.  <br />

B000ANVPPQ|5.0|The rare film that is impervious to criticism.  If you are not drawn into the infectuous fun of this film then nothing will grab you.  This film is reminiscent of the stylings of John Wayne's work with John Ford except Ford didn't direct this picture.  The film was directed by Andrew V. McLaglen, son of Victor, who apprenticed at the feet of Ford so that may explain the similarities.  This is a handsome, sprawling, boisterous package.  The cast seem to be having a great time here and they are not remiss in letting the audience in on the fun.  Not known as a comedian John Wayne displays a deft comic touch here and not just light comedy.  At times he seems to be improvising and going for broke with some hilarious broad comedy.  It may be the presence of Maureen O'Hara in the cast who always brought out the best work from the Duke.  O'Hara is no slouch either as displayed in the film's final scenes where she is required to act in her girdle.  Good supporting cast adds to the fun.  Recommended for not only fans of the Duke but fans of great comedy.

B000BM6AVA|2.0|It is very difficult to review this CD. First off, it is new, but believe me I've heard it enough to review it. First off, yes the music has changed, it has been changing for a LONG time, but that's not necessarily bad. As much as I liked the first CD, I still like songs like Roulette (and Holy Mountains on this CD). Not everything has to be grinding, up and down metal. So everyone that says they \\"sold out\\" on this CD needs to open their eyes and listen to every CD after the first one, you'll see this was coming.    My biggest problem, and it's the same problem I had with Mesmorize, is that Daron CAN NOT SING. I don't know why they felt the need to change things up like this. Serj isn't Pavarotti, but he brings so much emotion to the songs, while Daron's \\"singing\\" consists of him screaming incoherently. I was really frustrated with Mesmorize for this exact reason, and now I see they carried on this idea, much to the detriment of this CD.    Here's an analogy that might make more sense: imagine if suddenly someone started singing with Ozzy Osbourne on Black Sabbath songs. I'm not talking about Ronnie James, or David Coverdale, or Ian, or anyone like that. I mean imagine if Tony Iommi or Geezer Butler started singing half the songs with Ozzy. Would you look at things the same way? You'd probably be frustrated that Children of the Grave was now a duet, or that Iron Man now had harmonies. Of course most of you reviewing this CD are probably too young to have any idea what I'm talking about, but some people will understand this.    Don't take my word for it (or anybody's word for that matter), give the CD a listen, but I guess I just don't understand the need to bring in a far less-talented singer to supplement Serj.

B000053V7O|5.0|This review is for the 2001 Warner Brothers DVD.    It's 1959 in Paris with jazz saxophonist Dale Turner (Dexter Gordon) playing in the Blue Note Club.  His stage presence seems sedated as he sits rather than stands and holds the sax rigidly through most of set, but his music is mesmerizing.  His biggest fan, Francis Borler (Franois Cluzet) isn't inside the club, but outside in the rain, listening to every note as though his life depended on it.  As a struggling graphic artist, Francis doesn't have enough money to be inside the club, but one night after Turner leaves the Blue Note, he bumps into Francis and asks the Frenchman if he'll buy him a beer and Francis gladly accommodates Turner even though it will probably cost him all the money he has to his name.      Later it becomes clear that Turner has a drinking problem and all his close friends including his landlady try to isolate him from alcohol.  The film moves on with more great sessions inside the club, but one night Dale is picked up for public intoxication and from that point on Francis takes on the role as Dale's personal caretaker and even cajoles Turner into moving in with him and his young daughter into their small apartment.  The close-knit friendship continues with Turner being clean and sober.  Near the end of the film, Turner goes to back to America with Francis tagging along but Francis' visit is short lived as he decides to return to France.    The movie is the best jazz film I've seen, and it works magic because the main character is a real professional jazz musician and not an actor and the music is live and not piped in.  Having the movie take place in this small lounge in Paris, adds international appeal, warmth and a very personal connection to this brilliant art form.  As wonderful as the movie is, too much time was devoted to Borler's obsessive relationship with Turner.  This could have been the quintessential jazz film if it had focused more on Turner's relationship with other musicians with more discussions about the mechanics of the music.  By far, the best off-stage scene in the movie is when Turner has dinner with an attractive female singer whose been a longtime friend and she reminds Dale in a voice of gratitude, \\"You were the one that taught me to listen to the bass and not the drums\\" and Turner quickly replies back, \\"You would have figured it out in 10 or 15 years anyway\\".   The other thing that makes this film so special is the intimacy of the nightclub in a time when jazz musicians seemed far more accessible.  The final scene of the movie is many years later on a large stage of an amphitheater which is commonplace for today's jazz concerts and gives older jazz fans a longing for that golden age of bebop in those small clubs with special musicians who played like Dale Turner.  This is a must-have DVD for any serious jazz fan.    The DVD presentation is does the film justice.  The color widescreen presentation is immaculate and most importantly the stereo soundtrack sounds fantastic.        Movie: A-    DVD Quality: A
B00062J00S|5.0|If there was a film that represents American ideals, it would be this film.  George Baily is the epitomy of what is best in America.  A man that tries to live with values and morals without caving into big money/corporation.  He looks out for the little guy, and when he faulters and things look dire for ol' George, the town rallies behind him and his brother, the war hero, in the end, makes a toast to him:  \\"To George Baily.  The richest man in town.\\" How could you not love a movie like that?
B000BO0LLS|5.0|This is truly Mariah's comeback album and the return of the voice!  Having been certified 4x platinum and hitting #1 for 2 weeks (with her biggest one-week opener ever) in only a matter of 7 months, this album is on its way to being the biggest album of the year!  Pair this with the fact that Mariah's been doing this for around 15 years, sold around 230 million records and has had more #1 singles and spent more days on the top of the Billboard charts than any other female artist (second only to legends like the Beatles and Elvis), and it's easy to see that this woman has got a longevity and success that no one can match. This album would be a triumph, even without the success (in sales and critically) that it has received. It marks the return of a new Mariah - one that is happy again, no longer the laughingstock she was just years ago.  Mariah also returned to the award-winning streak she was on in the `90's, winning World Music, Soul Train, Teen Choice, Vibe, and numerous other awards.  She is up for five American Music Awards and is definitely a front-runner for a Grammy award - something she has not won since her debut!      Now, there are those that have complained that there have been four versions of the album.  In reality, there are only two.  At its initial release on April 12, the regular CD and a limited edition version (digipak with a poster) were released.  Note, the limited edition is NOT a re-release as they were released TOGETHER and people clearly had a choice to buy one or the other.  As well, the CD was exactly the same - no difference between the two.  There was only need to buy ONE of these two versions.  On November 15, the album was re-released with four extra tracks (all of which are amazing, by the way) as the Ultra Platinum Edition.  Again, there were two editions of this released -  the regular CD and a limited edition version (with a DVD).  The two versions, like the original, were both released on the SAME DAY and people are again, clearly given a choice as to which to buy!  So, why would anyone buy ALL editions of the album (unless a huge fan)?  Furthermore, the limited edition of the initial release was only widely available for a little while and was released in smaller quantities than the original album.  The limited edition of the re-release is MUCH better than the regular re-release version, so why are people complaining about 4 versions of the album?  So there is no reason to complain about this issue!  The only valid complaint would be that the company is milking the album by re-releasing it ONCE (the two new versions).  There is NO validity to the argument of the album being re-released 4 times, especially since you're getting so much more each time (unlike Usher's re-release, for example)!      Also, you don't HAVE to buy the album!  If you don't feel like paying for 4 new songs, then don't!  No one is controlling you and telling you to buy the album!  In addition, Mariah said that it was going to be a while before we hear a new album and since the new tracks are so good, who would want to wait that long to get new tracks?  EP's aren't exactly cheaper either and if you don't want to pay more for \\"what you already have\\", then just download the tracks from iTunes or other legal services (when they're available).  And to those who complain she does not care about her fans - umm...she did special signing sessions for her fans and has done many appearances / interviews / performances where she sincerely thanked her fans for everything!      And WHY are people comparing Mariah and Madonna's sales?  Or comparing them at all?  Both have their fans and have achievements, yet comparing them doesn't make either less or more than the other!  Both women are completely different and generally cater to different genres - both to pop, while Mariah is more aimed towards r&b/hip-hop audiences and Madonna more to dance audiences.  And it has been stated by many (basically everywhere) that Mariah is the best-selling female of all time!  True worldwide sales cannot be determined with accuracy, so there is no way one can debate that \\"fact\\".     1) It's Like That - The opening club-banging track and first single gets your ass shaking! The heavy bass and the feel-good lyrics will make you feel \\"lifted\\" and \\"you'll like it!\\" JD's part is extremely catchy and Fatman Scoop's rap, though brief, is very effective. Mariah showcases her voice brilliantly along with his hot rap at the end. Definitely one of the hottest dance tracks of the year and a great single to kick off this mint album!  The album's kick-off single entered the top 20 of the Billboard Hot 100, a huge return to the charts for Mariah (who hadn't charted in quite a while)!    2) We Belong Together - What more can I say about Mariah's 16th #1 Billboard Hot 100 single (spending an unbelievable 14 weeks at the top...second only to her '96 hit One Sweet Day at 16 weeks) and the song that set a record for MOST played song on American radio in a week?  Breaking countless other records and hitting #1 on 13 different Billboard charts (a record), this song shows you the power of Mariah and solidifies her place as the #1 female artist in the world!    3) Shake It Off - The 3rd single of the album, this track will make you \\"bounce\\"! A very light and catchy feel-good track, and hitting #2 on the Billboard Hot 100, this song will get stuck in your head in no time!     4) Mine Again - One of Mariah's best vocal performances in a long time, showcasing her near-perfect voice! Her effortless glide over the octaves is probably not as amazing as it once was, but this is the closest it's been in a long time! A true \\"song for the ages\\" as many call it.     5) Say Somethin' (feat. Snoop Dogg) - A hip-hop lover's dream: Mariah, Snoop Dogg, and the Neptunes! Hot, funky, and danceable track and extremely sexy, Mariah and Snoop have awesome chemistry in this one! `Nuff said!     6) Stay The Night - Mariah really belts in this one! One of Kanye's best, it has a 70's soul feel to it. Definitely one of the highlights on the album, again doing wonders at displaying Mariah's huge voice.     7) Get Your Number (feat. JD) - Released only overseas as a single, this is one of my favorite track of the album. Many have complained that JD is annoying and sounds like Nelly, but I think he does a great job. This is probably the best dance track on the album and the one you can see everyone clubbing to. An extremely fun song to sing along to and dance to!    8) One And Only (feat. Twista) - \\"Twista and Mariah, together like a grip on a tire!\\" These two really do fit well together and Mariah proves she can keep up with Twista's rapping in this hot and smooth track.  I thought this amazing pairing couldn't get better...that is until I heard One And Only Pt. 2 (see below for review)!    9) Circles - Another excellent mid-tempo R&B ballad with superb vocals, Mariah again samples old school music. This is definitely a song that only Mariah could pull off!  Simply amazing!    10) Your Girl - An upbeat, sexy song with more old-school vibes. Another feel-good track that'll make you sing along!     11) I Wish You Knew - A very nice ballad that many can relate to. Mariah pulls a Alicia Keys on this one and talks, while the audience applauds. Has a \\"show-y\\" feeling to it and makes you feel like you're watching this in a theatre. Again, showcasing Mariah's enormous range and control.     12) To The Floor (feat. Nelly) - The REAL Nelly is on this track and it's a very slick hip-hop track. Mariah uses a very subtle, sexy voice on this one, while Nelly goes easy on the song, not overdoing it. Hot beats and Mariah is again able to complement the rapping with her vocals.     13) Joyride - The most beautiful love song on the album and also the \\"poppiest\\" song of the album, though it also has an R&B feel to it. I think any pop artist could sing this song and I would love it, but Mariah makes it that much more special. For most of thesong, Mariah uses a very beautiful soft voice, but then belts at the end and hits some ridiculously high notes! Again, it is just lovely!     14) Fly Like A Bird - What a way to close the album (well the original version anyways)! Mariah's voice gets progressively stronger as the song goes on and it closes with a full choir. Mariah's voice simply soars on this song, filling you with joy and hope! This is Mariah at her best - her singing is almost ecstatic, a true throwback to some of her earlier stuff! Perfect!     15) Don't Forget About Us - The 4th US single from the album has been called an amalgamation of We Belong Together and Shake It Off.  Reproducing the feel and beat of We Belong Together, but also adding some \\"bounce\\" from Shake It Off (not to mention the chart and radio success of both!), this song does something even more important - it connects with people in so many ways and as Mariah says, it means something different to everyone.  It's just a beautiful song and Mariah sings with such emotion!  I definitely have a feeling that this is going to hit #1 and tie her with Elvis for number of #1 singles (17, second behind the Beatles).      16) Makin' It Last All Night (What It Do) (feat. JD) - This is a funky, sexy and fun track!  It has an urban feel to it and JD does a great job in the rapping department!  Definitely has the potential to be a single!    17) So Lonely (One And Only Pt. 2) (feat. Twista) - HOT TAMALE!  IMO, one of the best urban/hip-hop tracks Mariah has done - a song with a feel like 50 Cent's club-bangers but so much more!  Mariah lowers her voice to a sexy purr throughout the song, while Twista does what he does best!  This could definitely be another #1 hit for Mariah if released!      18) We Belong Together (Remix) (feat. Styles P. & Jadakiss) - Nothing can really top the original, but this DJ Clue mix comes close!  Starting with a soft \\"when you left I lost a part of me\\", the song speeds up and includes solid raps from Kiss and Styles, including this memorable line:  Show your respect   Whenever you hear me or see me   This is the emancipation of Mimi  Hot like a real fever, the real diva   So successful, yet still so eager...        The DVD features music videos for Mariah's four original singles from the album: It's Like That, We Belong Together, Shake It Off, and the previously unreleased (in the U.S.) Get Your Number!  The four vids represent some of Mariah's best and sexiest videos and are really works of art.  The first two were directed by Brett Ratner, while the latter two videos were done by Jake Nava.  The videos can be shown in order or separately.  The quality is excellent and the menus are simple, yet beautiful!  The DVD also has a link to Mariah's latest video (one of her best yet!) Don't Forget About Us and an interview done \\"in her own words\\"!  Both are great features, though it would have been much better if included on the DVD.  The quality of the bonus features are not that great and is quite a hassle (you need a computer and have to download some software), but still a great addition to the album!    Phew! This simply amazing album got even better! A perfect blend of hot, dance/hip-hop tracks and smooth, lovely r&b/pop ballads, with some old-school soul and gospel thrown in! I think the album is going to continue selling extremely well and I have no doubt that Mariah is going to keep on hitting the top of the charts with these excellent tracks, perhaps even reaching the Beatles and Elvis in terms of success on the Billboard charts before the end of the year! I think the verdict from critics and fans is pretty much clear: MIMI IS BACK!!!!!!

B00008RH1H|5.0|When it comes to film adaptations, most films fail in some way.  To think that a Japanese film director could transform one of the greatest plays written in the English language and mke it his own, is quite tremendous. To think that he could use Japanese Noh theater images to enhance the adpatation is a stroke of genius.  Mifune is one of the greatest actors to play Macbeth, and dare say maybe the best.  Akira Kurosawa directed a masterpiece and proves why he is at the top of the pantheon of great world directors.   <br />And, of course, The Criterion Collection folk out do themselves, again.  Thank goodness for them, because of it wasn't for them, we all would be missing out on great films.

Just the same when he is faced with the choice of whether or not to kill a man, it followed approximetly this train of thought, \\"I could walk away, but the sun is so bright, and he's sitting in the shade, maybe i should walk towards him and try to get out of the sun; oh no he pulled a knife and the sun is so bright!\\" Without further thought he shoot the man several times in cold blood, caring for nothing except that it is hot out.  <br /> <br />When Mersault is arrested, he makes no attempt to cover up his action, or to defend it in any way, even by hiring a lawyer. 0553801503|2.0|Let me start by pointing out what some might not know.  This book is half of the book that GRRM intended to write.  He took certain chapters from that book out to make this book and the rest will make up the next book.  Unfortunately, what he really needed to do was get someone to edit the original book down instead.    A Song of Ice and Fire is a series that is often layered in complexities, but so far the interesting stuff has come in such large doses that the complexity hasn't outweighed the interest factor.      I'm sorry to say that this book is more complex than interesting.  The amount of throwaway characters in the book is unwieldy.  There are over fifty pages of lists of the various factions and their associated personages in the back of the book and I really did need those at times.      There is a more narrow focus on the Westeros factions in this book with the Lannisters and Martells getting a lot of chapters.  Many of these characters and their followers share similar names or even sometimes the same names and then GRRM mixes names with titles and it starts to get even more headache inducing. All this would probably have been forgiven if the majority of the book held my interest, but often I found myself skimming over the listings of bannermen, nobles or followers trying to keep moving along.    Then there are the individuals we follow in this book.  Jaime and Cersei Lannister get a large share of this book and they are just damned annoying.  Jaime is screwed up over his hand being chopped off and his father dying and Cersei is just completely amoral and nuts as she takes over as Queen.  Their inner dialogue often gets repetitive and predictable, especially Cersei.    Brienne of Tarth also gets a large share of the book as she tries to search out Sansa Stark.  The problem is that we know she isn't going to find Sansa where she is looking, so often it seems like her plotline is going nowhere.    Sansa is still in the Eyrie with Littlefinger and not muchhappens there for most of the book.  Arya is in Braavos and her chapters are some of the more interesting ones, but she doesn't make up for the various Greyjoy family members we have to follow around in the book.  They just don't fill out as characters very well.  They're too one-dimensional.    Overall, there is a lot of plotting and maneuvering in this book and not much action.  There were several plotlines that just felt like filler in this one, plotlines that could have been summed up in a few lines of dialogue somewhere else. I'm afraid the book just doesn't hold together as well as the past books.  Except for Cersei and Jaime most of the characters never interact with each other, in turn the storylines feel very disconnected from each other.  Here's hoping the second half of this novel works better.

B000B8QEZG|5.0|Confessions On A Dance Floor is perhaps the first album since her debut to be so consistently great, track-by-track. Unlike other albums people often put forward as her best--Like A Prayer and Ray of Light, for instance--there isn't a weak song on the album. Let me go through each one... <br /> <br />Hung Up: Surely, you've heard this by now. The ABBA sample is some of the most effective sampling I've heard in dance music; it's simple, instrumental, and blends perfectly with the chorus. One thing that's often missing in mainstream attempts at electronica is moments of really slowing it down, having sections of the song that break down the song and give it a chance to breath and meditate before building to a hard, killer beat. This is something DJ's do constantly in actual clubs and raves but is usually absent in mainstream dance CD's, but this song does it and does it well, with a lot of tick-tocking. <br /> <br />Get Together: This is the first of a series of more ambient, vocador-heavy songs. She repeatedly goes for a style of electronica that is most well-known in hits like Stardust's The Music Sounds Better With You but was actually pretty widespread in 90's electronica. It is a vaguely emotional but also somewhat detached style of ambient electronica, and she (largely thanks to Stuart Price) surpasses the vast majority of the stuff in that style that was going around in the 90's. <br /> <br />Sorry: This is probably the best song on the album. It's one of the all-time best tell-off/break-up club anthems. Anyone who listens to a lot of house music knows how many diva vocal driven dance songs have come out over the years with the same message: I'm so over you, I'm such a strong woman, so get out of my life (I'm paraphrasing, of course, but there are countless songs like this). This is one of the best ones anyone's ever done. <br /> <br />Future Lovers: This is another one of the ambient electronica songs. These generally aren't meant to be as single-oriented, since they're influenced by a style that never broke into the mainstream. This is a better example than Get Together, in my opinion, because it uses Madonna's always-great spoken word sexy muttering and also has a very original, quirky central melody. <br /> <br />I Love New York: Unlike most New York tribute songs that are naively optimistic and upbeat, this song conveys the edgy feeling of the actual city with its hard, aggressive beat. The production is similar to that of Basement Jaxx's album Rooty, and she expresses her love for the city by capturing its grit (despite her apparent unwillingness to use the actual f-word). Much more effective, in a way, than other New York tributes. <br /> <br />Let It Will Be: Great production, excellent example of bringing together a simple, strings melody with a dance beat. Some people say the strings are from Papa Don't Preach, but that's not true. <br /> <br />Forbidden Love: Another one of the ambient songs. This has a beautiful melody and is more emotional than the previous ones. People say this album has no meaning, but here we see that, at times, it's just as emotional as her other albums, just in a more subtle style. <br /> <br />Jump: I believe this may be a single... It's not quite on the level of Sorry, but it's easy to imagine this being a huge anthem that you hear at every club you go to. <br /> <br />How High: Originally written for a musical Madonna planned to star in, this is a lot better than most of the \\"the trouble with being famous\\"-type songs. Unlike Substitute For Love, for instance, it's not about wallowing in self-pity, and it just has a very strong melody. <br /> <br />Isaac: This one was controversial for some reason. I don't understand why. Basically, she got a guy to do some religious chanting/singing and built a dance song around his little chant. Similar to Shanti/Aghanti from Ray of Light but probably stronger overall and more danceable. It is actually pretty effective in making you feel very spiritual without sounding at all preachy or self-righteous. Yet again, some great use of strings and spoken word. <br /> <br />Push: This has harder, hip hop oriented verses and a slower, more emotional chorus. Actually the verses sound like choruses, so it's one of these songs that feels like it's alternating between two equally catchy hooks. <br /> <br />Like It Or Not: This is probably the best closer of any of her albums. As many have pointed out, it's downtempo, but when this album ends and you hear the central lyrics of this song, you feel like she's really made her case for being the best pop star in the world. She sings \\"This is who I am / You can like it or not / You can love me or leave me / But I'm never gonna stop.\\" And after over 20 years of great pop music and at the end of one of her most consistent albums, those lines really sum it up perfectly. She's not trying to win everyone over, she's just being the pure pop star that she was when she started. And the reality is that she does it better than anyone in the world, and I can't think of anyone else who could put out such a consistent piece of pop music in the third decade of their career.
B00003CX8U|4.0|All That Jazz is a semi-autobiographical film about director, choreographer, and dancer Bob Fosse. Fosse was a Chicago native who used tour with vaudeville groups until he made it to Broadway. As a choreographer, he was well known for his sexualized movements and penchant for fishnets and bowler hats. The movie stars Roy Schneider as Joe Gideon cum Bob Fosse-- a chain-smoking tyrant of a choreographer with an ego as huge a his sexual appetite for women. Roy Schneider does a great job of assuming the sinewy characteristics of a life-long dancer.<br /><br />Bob Fosse co-wrote and directed All That Jazz. ATJ gives us a peek inside the genius of Fosse. It is a fantastical story told as part musical, docudrama, and camp. (When Joe Gideon's alter-ego leans in beside the real Gideon, in bed after heart surgery, and whispers \\"cue hospital hallucination, you know, finally, that this is no ordinary flick.) Fosse skewers not only the financiers of Broadway musicals and the women he bedded, he also sticks it to himself the hardest. Gideon is such a jerk that when he is faced with a heart attack from years of drinking, screwing and pill-popping, you can't decide if you want him to live or die.<br /><br />All that Jazz is a movie that requires concentration with the quick cuts from Joe's present to his past and into his imagination. There are also several viewings of Joe's daily routine (The routine consists of Joe popping a pill, using eye drops, taking a shower, shaking the pain out of his wrist, and then facing himself in the mirror to utter \\"Show time.\\"). At first, the repetitions come off as annoying but eventually you realize it is a comparison of learning a dance. You repeat and repeat and repeat until you get it right. (And once it hits the stage, you repeat and repeat and repeat for 8 shows a week.) The theme of repetition and perfection come up in the film often.<br /><br />Joe is working on a film project that is overdue to the movie company ( in real life it is a version of Bob Fosse's biographical film Lenny based on the life of comedian Lenny Bruce). He relentlessly watches the draft over and over again finding every flaw but never finding what good is in it. From every dance that is rehearsed ad nauseum to the parade of women that come in and out of Joe's life, his mere existence is about repetition until perfection but he never finds it. This movie, however, is as close to perfect as a bio-pic can get (witty, sexy, good music, great dancing, excellent acting).<br /><br />All that Jazz also takes me back to the late 70s and early 80s when Broadway musicals seemed to having a revival in NYC. I fondly remember seeing commercials on television for Evita, Dreamgirls, A Chorus Line, Annie, La Cage Aux Folles and other favorites. I also remember hearing songs from those musicals played on the radio--re-edited and discofied for everyone. All that Jazz and Cabaret melded into one for me as kid. Life, theater, and the movies were just one big song and dance routine.is a version of Bob Fosse's biographical film Lenny based on the life of comedian Lenny Bruce). He relentlessly watches the draft over and over again finding every flaw but never finding what good is in it. From every dance that is rehearsed ad nauseum to the parade of women that come in and out of Joe's life, his mere existence is about repetition until perfection but he never finds it. This movie, however, is as close to perfect as a bio-pic can get (witty, sexy, good music, great dancing, excellent acting).  <br /> <br />All that Jazz also takes me back to the late 70s and early 80s when Broadway musicals seemed to having a revival in NYC. I fondly remember seeing commercials on television for Evita, Dreamgirls, A Chorus Line, Annie, La Cage Aux Folles and other favorites. I also remember hearing songs from those musicals played on the radio--re-edited and discofied for everyone. All that Jazz and Cabaret melded into one for me as kid. Life, theater, and the movies were just one big song and dance routine.
B000002J6H|3.0|If you leave out the Up-With-People choruses and the sophomoric politics of America's Children, then this album is pretty damn good. There's no Bluebird or Suite Judy Blue Eyes here, but there is some incredible picking, great songs, and an overall vibrance found lacking in Crosby and Nash's albums.    There just aren't too many artists who could have a Latin-flavored hit single, a gorgeous folk ballad, a guitar-choking acoustic blues workout, a jazzy organ number with Hendrix on-board, AND an Albert King-inspired strut that featured one of Eric Clapton's best recorded solos, and all on a debut solo album. It was a sign of the times that a work so diverse could end up in the #2 spot for the year.     Mr. Stills did go a little too far, though, by over-polishing this effort, and by having everybody who was on the block that day sing in an overblown gospel chorus style.    Stephen Barncard, engineer for C,S& N, has said that Jimi Hendrix played an incredible solo on Love The One You're With, but Stills erased it, and put steel drums on instead. It was the last thing Jimi ever recorded. It's this sort of thing that gets Stills in trouble with the critics.

0553801503|2.0|The Phantom Editor <br /> <br />When \\"The Phantom Menace\\" was released a few years ago, everyone expected it to be on of the greatest films they'd ever seen.  However, this was unfotunately not the case.  It was simply not a very good movie.  I really *wanted* to like the movie.  I really did.  But when I found myself needing to search for positives in order to combat the overwhelming list of negatives, I realized it was time to concede defeat.  There were/are still some holdouts that say things like \\"This was a transition movie\\" or \\"Even the greatest filmmakers can't make every movie their greatest\\" or \\"Expectations were set so high, it was doomed no matter how good it was\\".  These are theoretically valid arguments, with the only problem that they are false.  The movie just isn't that good - period. <br /> <br />Also unfortunate is that this is exactly how I feel about Feast for Crows, the latest in Martin's juggernaut series.  I really want to like this book.  In fact, I really really really want to like this book.  I've been able to do nothing but sing the series' praise from the mountaintop since I first started reading it several years ago.  But once again, I find myself searching for positives, which is a clear indicator that the book has issues - huge issues.  Just think - did the thought ever, ever cross your mind after finishing Storm of Swords - \\"What are some positive things about this book?\\"  No - it would be a completely unneccesary exercise, to the point of absurdity.  Not so here.  I now find myself remembering \\"moments\\", and that's a crying shame. <br /> <br />\\"This is a transition book\\".  Several reviewers have made this statement.  It reminds me of the phrase \\"street smarts\\".  Just what are \\"street smarts\\"?  They are what all people who don't have \\"book smarts\\" automatically assume they have.  Just because a book is lacking in plot development or interest, that doesn't automatically make it a \\"transition book\\".  In a transition book, you can stillpoint to character development, and situations that have transpired that will allow something big and exciting to happen in a future book.  There was very little of that in this book.  Reading a good transition book is like watching a couple of Grandmasters play a positional middle game in chess.  A lot of pieces are moved, but there are very few piece captures.  Instead, each Grandmaster is quietly setting up for the Big Moment - instead of excitement, there is tension.  In Martin's case, it's like he was trying to emulate the Grandmasters, but didn't execute correctly.  Instead, he superglued the pieces to the board, and then shook it up and down real fast.  None of them went ANYWHERE, even though they was a lot of commotion about them. <br /> <br />\\"But what about Cercei - there was a lot of development there!\\" you may say.  Well, I'm not sure how to characterize what happened to her, other than as a character she was ruined.  She had INCREDIBLE potential to be a fascinating character, but somewhere between book 3 and 4 she overdosed on stupid-pills.  I mean, this was the primary enemy of TYRION.  She fought an incredible mental/political battle with one of the finest minds in the Seven Kingdoms for 3 books.  She was a mega-player!!!  But as soon as we get into her head, she becomes one of the more phenominally inept characters in modern fantasy. <br /> <br />Many reviewers have brought up other points that I fully agree with and will not duplicate here, save one.  There was a character in the Phantom Menace called \\"Jar Jar Binks\\".  Pretty much everyone in the world (except for the very young and the very old) hated him with a passion.  Not only was he extremely annoying, he was extremely unnecessary.  Some creative folks took the brilliant initiative to edit out all of the scenes with Jar-Jar Binks from the Phantom Menace, which was subsequently passed around the internet (I'm in no way condoning that part of it).  The movie became MUCH more enjoyable this way -it was much shorter, you didn't have to suffer through Jar-Jar, and you DIDN'T MISS ANY OF THE PLOT.  The title of this version was \\"The Phantom Edit\\".   <br /> <br />Well, this character also exists in Feast For Crows.  Although Brienne isn't quite as annoying as Jar-Jar, she's even *more* unneccesary, and takes up *way* more real estate.  The book could use a good Phantom Editor.  Please, someone re-release this book with the Brienne chapters removed.  I know I can simply skip them, but it's just not the same. <br /> <br /> There is something much scarier than extraneous and/or annoying characters in this book; something that not as many people have mentioned that I find a little surprising.  The quality of the writing itself has plummeted; specifically, the writing has gotten way too descriptive, almost like Martin needed space filler (although I strongly believe this is not the case).  There are 3 main areas I break these fillers into.  1) The  \\"List\\".  If someone meets a singer, you don't need to spend  of a page on a list of 34 song titles the singer knows.  Or if there is a discussion of rumors from a far-off land (especially if we know the truth already), don't spend a whole page listing variations on the truth, and end with \\"the one thing they all had in common was --insert truth here--\\".  2) \\"The Clothes\\".  This one was WAY too Jordan-ish for me.  Every time a character meets someone else, or goes somewhere else, there is a love-fest of clothing and hair descriptions, heraldry/family trees, building descriptions, etc, etc, etc.  Some description is clearly needed to set the environment, but there is such a thing as going to far, and Martin crossed that boundary more often than not. 3) Speaking of love-fest, what's up with George \\"Skinemax\\" Martin?  I'm certainly not a prude, nor did I find the sexual references in the first few books difficult to read.  After all, there was usually some purpose/relevance.  But in this book, most of the time there is no purpose for the sex.  And it happens in almost every chapter (except the Brienne chapters of course, although there are refereces aplenty!)  <br /> <br />In any case, there was some serious editing needing to be done.  I sincerely hope this was a blip on the radar, and that Dance with Dragons will bring us right back up to speed. <br />
0671027387|2.0|This book didn't have me \\"so hooked I couldn't put it down\\" was more of - a couple of chapters before lights out.<br /><br />Main Characters reminded me of Sunset Beach (the soap opera).<br /><br />Gabriel Ashe & Rachel Sexton should have had a fight over a man or two, shame the only contender was Michael Tolland who seemed like a bit of a wimp (or wet fish)He could have done with a sinister side to make him more interesting.<br /><br />I liked the escape from the bad guys across the ice & the way emergency code was picked up by the sub. B00008VGL6|4.0|This beautiful little covers album is not, of course, a Depeche Mode album. It doesn't have the production investment behind it or a point to prove. But it is a wonderful discovery of torch songs, beautifully sung with minimal instrumentation and basic but very satisfying production. Many of the songs are far from immediate but the album has grown steadily on me for the past two years and is now becoming a favourite. The choice of songs is unusual and brave- not many would take on an Alvin Stardust cover- but Martin Gore brings a uniquely beautiful darkness to each song. He understands perfectly the crossover between glam rock and the darker side of Bowie albums such as Low. What we get is a dark modern electronic take on that.  <br /> <br />The strongest track is probably his cover of Julie Cruise's In My Other World which is very atmospheric and has a haunting guitar riff. But his versions of Nick Cave's Loverman and Iggy Pop's Tiny Girls are joys to behold. The album ends with a narcotic rendition of The Velvet Underground's Candy Says which envelopes the listener. I would recommend the album to anyone who likes Martin Gore's songs on the Depeche Mode albums and is used to appreciating independent music. This is free from the shackles of major label input and you'll never hear a collection of songs like it- unless, of course, Martin Gore releases another one. Given the 14 year interlude between Counterfeit and Counterfeit2 it's unlikely but I, for one, hope he will. <br /> <br /> <br />

0793563836|5.0|I bought this book with the CDs because it came highly recommended.   I didn't know how to read regular music notation but knew I needed to learn - TAB can only get you so far.  <br /> <br />This book breaks down the notation a little at a time while providing great little tunes from the CD to play with. Each tune is a full band track - very cool! <br /> <br />I tend to be a little impatient and skipped ahead to some more tunes on the CD. I couldn't figure out why I sounded off. I then went back to read all of the notes in the book to that point. I soon found what the natural sign does - it cancels the sharps and flats in a measure. It's the little details like this that make the book VERY useful - Ed Friedland doesn't assume you know everything(which is good). <br /> <br />The main reason I bought this book was because I couldn't keep going to a bass teacher at the moment, for financial reasons. This book is great when you are on your own. But, when I can resume lessons, I will surely ask about using this book in our lessons.

The studio version is even better. One of my favorite tracks right now. <br />4.Hypnotize- we all have heard this by now. It is definitely a surprise because it is a different direction for SOAD. I love it though because it has a punk feel to it towards the end. <br />5.Stealing Society- Daron and Serj alternate vocals on this one and it is crazy! Might be my favorite overall at the moment. <br />6.Tentative- slower than the previous tracks, but still a powerful song. <br />7.U-Fig- excellent guitar work on this track. <br />8.Holy Mountains- this track was floating around the net and sounded awesome. the studio version does it justice as it sounds excellent. slower type of song but very strong, I am impressed. <br />9.Vicinity of Obsenity- this is the craziest song on the album. chorus repeats \\"banana banana banana, terra cotta pie\\". It is hard to find the meaning of this track but Serj is all over the place in this one ripping it to shreds.  <br />10.She's Like Heroin- Daron stars in this track. this is a terrific song, one of their best I think.  <br />11.Lonely Day- my least favorite of the 12 tracks. Dont get me wrong, it is a good song but it is so plain that a lot of people may not like it. Probably the slowest song from any System album. <br />12.Soldier Side- WOW! this track is unbelievable. It picks up where Soldier Side Intro left off on Mezmerize, and I think these are the most personal and emotionally strong lyrics System has written. It ends the album on a very high note, leaving you Mezmerized and Hypnotized over what you just heard. <br /> <br />I hope this persuades some new listeners to check this band out. The true fans don't need any persuasion. I have been a huge fan since the self-titled album and I am completely amazed by Hypnotize. If you thought Mezmerize brought them to new heights, you haven't heard anything yet.

B0002TX4QQ|5.0|First of, let me say that I have absolutely no connection to the author.  I stumbled upon this book by a review in THE ECONOMIST and thought it sounded interesting.   <br /> <br />I was stunned within the first few pages. <br />WE NEED TO TALK ABOUT KEVIN opens brilliantly and just keeps going, like an arrow hitting its target dead center.  I had to read this in spurts because it was incredibly painful but when I read, I spent hours reading.  And I found myself re-reading passages to make sure I caught everything. I found myself marvelling as I read -- the language was beautiful, each word precise and perfectly chosen, every sentence loaded with meaning. <br /> <br />Shriver has delivered what I think is a novel as perfect as any in classic literature.  This, for me, is on the level of HUCKLEBERRY FINN, JANE EYRE, TO KILL A MOCKINGBIRD and the best comparison: FRANKENSTEIN.  Those are well-structured, beautifully written and narrated in a PITCH PERFECT voice.   <br /> <br />I have sold at least three copies of the book already...I hope this review sells more.  This is something you want to own and re-read, if only to learn how to write.
0671027344|4.0|This is a great book about kid named Charlie. He is going into high school. Being scared, he decides he needs to talk to someone, other than a psychiatrist. The book is composed of all of Charlie's letters to someone who he heard \\"listens and understands and doesn't try to sleep with you at a party\\". In this nameless person, Charlie confides all of his hopes, dreams, memories, and worries. His brother has left for college, his best friend Michael died, and all he really wants is some friends. Thankfully, he ends up with the best friends in the whole school: Sam, Patrick, Alice, and Mary Elizabeth. Charlie chronicles his life as a freshman by dates, football games, parties, and the special books given to him by his English teacher. He goes through a lot of tough times, trying to \\"participate\\" and not just listen in the corner of the room. When these struggles seem to become too much, he turns to drugs.  <br /> I really liked that the main character was about my age. I could relate to the book a lot. All Charlie's friends were really into having debates, reading poetry, and listening to punk music. These things, I think, sound like fun. Charlie is not an \\"average\\" teenager, which made me appreciate this book a lot. What he wanted were friends, not a girlfriend or boyfriend. He is totally different than most students, but some people were able to look past that to be his friend. The only thing I didn't like about this book was all the curse words. It would have been just as good without them I think. One other thing I didn't like was that in the story, a girl got an abortion. Charlie helped the girl. That was the one part in the book that I thought Charlie was doing the wrong thing. <br /> I think just about any high school kid would like this book because they can relate to what Charlie is going through.
