B000BJS4SU|4.0|Having been lucky enough to catch the John Mayer Trio in Minneapolis, I was eager to hear how accurately this CD recreated the show.  It was my second live experience with Mr. Mayer, having caught him in an arena setting with Guster the previous year. In that environment, it seemed like John was trying to live up to the Dave Matthews comparisons, with his Any Given Thursday band, plus a horn section, a pianist, and some backing vocalist/acoustic guitarist for some reason.  Songs like \\"Come Back To Bed\\" were interminably stretched to ten-plus minutes, and the proceedings had an air of self-indulgence.  Mayer seemed to have caught whiff of this, as he stripped down to the bare minimum, flanking himself with two peerless professionals in the form of Steve Jordan and Pino Palladino.  Not only was the band pared, but the venues as well, with the Trio performing at small clubs for a few hundred people.  And the indulgence was strictly in the richness of his musical influences, with the platinum-selling albums and their hits all but forgotten.  At the show I attended, the band opened with an awesome version of \\"Every Day I Have The Blues\\" before launching into \\"Who Do You Think I Was\\" which starts things off here.  The song rocks, if having a few too many winks (\\"Is he the one who turns the ladies on?\\"), along with the old LP-style liner notes and the \\"Connecticut\\" line slightly taking away from the otherwise deep sincerity.  Other highlights include \\"Good Love Is On The Way\\", featuring the catchiest riff of the album, and the original bluesy treatment of \\"Daughters\\" which suits the song much better. Steve Jordan adds so much vitality in his drumming and backing vocals, while Pino anchors the proceedings admirably (not unlike his predecessor in The Who).  Some surprises would have been nice; as another reviewer said, I would have loved to have heard a band version of \\"Love Soon\\", one of Mayer's best songs, or even the obscure \\"George's Blues\\" for laughs. \\"Something's Missing\\" is a little redundant, even though it was slightly rewritten since its debut on Any Given Thursday. I still have great admiration for Mayer virtually starting the group's setlist from scratch.  Thankfully the mixers have taken down the audience in the mix so as not to overwhelm the musicians.  I can attest that even though he didn't play \\"Wonderland\\" or \\"Come Back To Bed\\", the girls in the audience used their upper registers in unison multiple times, which inflicted far more strain on my ears than the amplifiers.  Simultaneously, I was quite impressed by how eager men and women in my age group were willing to follow the Trio's blues excursions, and hopefully those who didn't make the shows will catch some of that infectiousness here.   A highly satisfying start for the Trio (I suspect it will have more replay value than previous J.M. live releases), and hopefully they won't be just an experimental stunt. An enthusiastic four stars, since we reserve five for stuff like Live At Leeds.
B000A2WF3S|5.0|Gidon Kremer has again recorded the Sonatas and Partitas for Solo Violin of Bach and while his facility and technical grace are intact, in this recording he appears to have been deeply influenced by his time with the moderns (Adams, P&auml;rt, Schnittke, Piazzola, Glass, et al).  For this listener it seems that studying and performing these contemporary composers' manipulation of sound and instrumental scope has enriched Kremer's thought about the perfection of Bach.<br /><br />Not everyone will agree with Kremer's approach to these works on this new recording, but for those who know Bach's solo violin pieces there are pleasures in store.  Remaining technically suave and with a luxuriant tone, Kremer seems to be communicating with the psychological Bach, offering different tempi and more soulful approaches than those of his colleagues. The results are mesmerizing.<br /><br />The sonics of this release are impeccable: the soloist is immediately in the room with the listener.  This recording is a must for those who have followed Kremer's impressive career and for those who wish to venture outside the norm for a fresh approach to the wonders of Bach's genius.  Highly recommended. Grady Harp, November 05
B0006L16N8|1.0|There are so many reasons to hate coldplay. I sometimes find it difficult to believe that such inoffensive music manages to offend me so much, but it does. When I hear Fix You come on the radio it makes me so angry - not with the band, who are \\"just trying to connect with people\\" in the most commercially viable way - but with the people that actually bought it. Have you lost your minds? At what point did you stop actually thinking about music and BUY THIS CRAP?! Chris Martin is perhaps one of the few people around that can combine being insipid with being surprisingly arrogant. It comes across in his interviews, his singing voice, his lyrics...so why buy it?    Their early songs - shiver, yellow, and the scientist - were fairly pleasant, romantic pop songs. They were bland, sure, but they didn't make you want to rip your own ears off. Songs like Fix You, however,  seem perfectly calculated to create previously unsuspected levels of nausea in even the most casual of listeners, and it's astonishing. I blame U2 for this, as Coldplay suddenly seemed to become obsessed with plagarising U2 instead of Radiohead (they probably make more money). However, even the pompous U2 aren't this obnoxious, and that is saying something.    Lets analyse this!  \\"When you lose something you can't replace  When you love someone, but it goes to waste  Could it be worse?\\"  Yes, it really could be. Perhaps Mr Martin intends for us to fill in the gaps here: the loss of \\"something\\" could refer to the use of your four limbs, or maybe your entire family in a bomb blast. But Coldplay are too preoccupied with trying to please as many people as they can so they can take their money off them. The result of this is me having to listen to people singing along to these lyrics whilst revelling in self pity and feeling really \\"deep\\", when actually theyre just thinking about how they're having a bad hair day, or maybe how they've been ripped off by Apple's built-in obsilesance policy on iPods.       My question is, how can music publications like Q magazine give 5 star reviews for this album with a straight face? With no hint of irony? I have concluded that it is all part of a cynical ploy to sell more magazines, more albums, to more mindless, dribbling idiots.  Overall this music makes me sad. If you want to feel good about music then listen to some good bands - Radiohead (infinitly better than Coldplay), the White Stripes (they took 2 weeks to make their latest, brilliant album - Coldplay took 2 years to make this monumental piece of rubbish) or the Beatles. But then, just anything is better than this. Even U2.

B00006L7XQ|5.0|This was the last album recorded by Johnny Cash. And in his farewell (I think he knew this would be the last time around) Cash reflects on his long and prodigious career with a satisfying album such as this one. <br /> <br />Johnny Cash is a member of the Million Dollar Quartet, that is a group of four entertainers including Cash, Carl Perkins, Jerry Lee Lewis, and Elvis Presley who began recording on the Sun label in Memphis at the dawn of the Rock and Roll age. Cash the only one we have really had a chance to see age, and that's what endears him to so many people. You can listen to him age in voice, body, mind, and soul all the way from his early recordings like \\"Walk the Line,\\" and \\"Folsom Prison Blues,\\" to this album which includes CASH covers of \\"Hurt\\" among others. 0894803123|4.0|This book provides an introduction into the science of ice cream making, Ben & Jerry's style.  It begins with a short history of the Ben & Jerry's ice cream story-don't skip this part-it's quite amusing in places.  Then they bring on the main event, the ice cream recipes, first the bases, then the variations.  Following this is a section on other desserts and sweets to be served with the ice cream, delicacies like super-fudge brownies and whipped cream.<br /><br />One aspect I really like about this book is that they generally use just the 3 different ice cream bases provided at the beginning of the book.  All the remaining recipes rely on one of those bases, but they add instructions about quantities of other ingredients and how to prepare them before adding them to the ice cream.  This approach enables novice ice cream makers to really get a handle on the science of making ice cream, rather than having to deal with entirely new recipes each time. Ben and Jerry include in their recipes numerous tips for success-it's clear that they didn't simply try these recipes out in a test kitchen.  These guys actually had to try sell the results to customers, a much higher quality standard than just seeing if the taste was passable.  This book is one of the most used recipes books in our kitchen, not only for ice cream recipes, but for other essentials, like the giant chocolate chip cookie recipe (it even beat grandma's chocolate chip cookie recipe-no small feat!).<br /><br />The only drawback to the book is its reliance on raw eggs in a great number of the recipes.  Perhaps it was safe to put eggs in your ice cream without cooking them back in the 80s when this book was written, but you should really think twice before doing so now.  These days, thanks to factory egg farms, you have to assume that supermarket eggs are contaminated with salmonella even inside the shells, so you must cook them well before eating them, and especially before serving anything made with eggs to small children or older folks.  Freezing doesn't kill bacteria-it just slows growth down a bit, so if an egg contains salmonella and goes into ice cream uncooked, the results could be disastrous. To be on the safe side, either cook the ingredients for the ice cream bases that include eggs over a low heat until they thicken, then chill before freezing, or use eggs from sources you know to be salmonella free.to small children or older folks.  Freezing doesn't kill bacteria-it just slows growth down a bit, so if an egg contains salmonella and goes into ice cream uncooked, the results could be disastrous. To be on the safe side, either cook the ingredients for the ice cream bases that include eggs over a low heat until they thicken, then chill before freezing, or use eggs from sources you know to be salmonella free.

Kudos to you James for defying all of the non-believers and paving a new way to recovery!

0064407667|3.0|The Baudelaire children live in comfort and security, wholesome, inventive, intelligent children until one day while at the beach they receive devastating news. Their parents have been killed during a house fire, and all of their worldly belongings have also been destroyed in the pyre. An associate of their parents, a banker named Mr. Poe, takes them in for a few days, but then informs them that they are going to live with an obscure, somewhat estranged, relative on the opposite end of town, an actor by the name of Count Olaf.<br /><br />At first the Count seems to be an eccentric, a man who's house has fallen into disrepair and a shabby state of neglect. The Baudelaire children are horrified at the atrocious state of affairs that is to be their new home, and also the fact that there is only one bed in their \\"Room\\", and no crib for the youngest child, Sunny. Things go from bad to worse as they are assigned labor intensive chores from Count Olaf, including making supper for him and his theatre troupe friends one evening... all 13 of them.<br /><br /> Count Olaf quickly degenerates from an old eccentric to an abusive, fowl mouthed drunk, and the children, of course, suspect his motives for taking them in in the first place. Violet, the eldest, stands to inherit a fortune when she comes of age, and Olaf is aware of this, and concocts a plan to \\"marry\\" her onstage, or he will harm the youngest child, whom he has locked up in his tower... apparently the requirements for marriage in this community are quite simple, and with a few minor necessities provided the Count can perform the wedding and seize control of the Baudelaire's entire fortune, however the children have a few tricks up their sleeve to prevent this from occurring.<br /><br />This is one of those books that I probably would have loved as a child. Reading it, as an adult, I can see the merit to it, but I am no longer entertained by it. The story was cute, but predictable, the characters were fun, but meant to amaze other children. The writing was clear and flowed well, however their were things that got annoying after a while, for example the author's usage of vocabulary lessons in the middle of sentences. I see why he is doing this, but it gets irritating quickly. The book, however was a fun read, I think I polished it off in a little over an hour. It's a bit reminiscent of Dahl's work, which I still love, so I will give the author some credit there. I am mildly interested to see what else happens in some of the other books, but I don't know that I will be rushing out to read them all any time soon. I think children will love this book, however. I know I probably would have.but meant to amaze other children. B00005JNBQ|4.0|Within 20 minutes you will know if you're going to love or hate this film.  There is a general story line here:  a particularly nerdy high school boy stumbles through life, aware that he is often treated poorly, but apparently oblivious to his own idiosyncracies.  Various themes are touched upon:  family dysfunction, geeks get girls, and how self-confidence can overpower even near-constant peer negativity. <br /> <br />Nevertheless, the enjoyment Dynamite offers is in the over-all effect of this clumsy, often clueless hero plowing through life, successfully overcoming a constant flow of obstacles.  In the end, good hearts win, and sometimes even jerks can find redemption. <br /> <br />There is no doubt that this offering is quirky, quite weird, and will prove grating to some viewers. B000B8QEZG|5.0|Madonna's Confessions on a Dance Floor is a welcome return to what she does best--making shameless dance pop! I'm not going to review every song here, but will cover a few highlights.<br /><br />First a word about INSTRUMENTATION: Overall, the album has a full, almost orchestral quality. Basslines are deep, growling and pulsating. Live- and synth-strings accent Madonna's vocals, and while this is an electronic album overall, it sounds and feels very organic. Others have likened it to \\"Producing a Phil Spector `Wall of Sound'-style album for the dance floor\\"--and I agree!<br /><br />The much talked-about CONTINUOUS MIX of the album is done extremely well. It's not the `128 beats of unremarkable overlap between each song' that one typically hears on DJ-mix CDs. It is a more traditional, symphonic style of segueing between songs. In some cases, the songs are simply butted together and sound seamless because they share a consistent tempo and instrumentation. In other cases, a final melody from one song will carry into the next, subtly fading away during the first verse. The effect is almost unnoticeable during a casual listen, but music aficionados will find themselves listening to these transitions over and over, picking up new details on which instruments are from the previous track, and which are from the next. It's an elegant and amazing effect.<br /><br />Now, for the songs: Rumor has it WB is considering five singles. I'm sure you know \\"Hung Up\\" by now, so let's skip to other likely candidates.<br /><br />JUMP - Easily the best song on the album, and far better than Hung Up. Likely to be single #3. Madonna's vocal delivery is somewhere between \\"Keep it Together\\" and \\"Rescue Me\\", and she sells the song beautifully. It also has an incredible string obbligato part similar to the one in \\"Causing a Commotion.\\" At about 120 BPM the rhythm is reminiscent of Information Society, and the tempo is excellent for dance pop. Expect great remixes in the 128-130 range on this one (Hello WB? Ralphi Rosario please!)<br /><br />SORRY - Rumored to be single #2. A great song which, following the more straightforward Hung Up and Get Together, has a frantic pace in comparison. Reminiscient of her \\"Till Death Do Us Part,\\" but without the unhappy subject matter. This one is all fun, energy, and sass.<br /><br />HOW HIGH - Has that slight postpunk/pop rhythm, similar to Kylie Minogue's \\"Come into My World.\\" One of the few truly introspective songs on the album, but despite being in a minor (or diminished, I can't quite tell) key, it is not the least bit depressing. It comes across as defiant. Not the sure-bet that Jump and Sorry are, but in an edited length it can be a radio hit.<br /><br />FUTURE LOVERS - Recreates the bubbling, pulsating bassline from Donna Summer's \\"I Feel Love,\\" however here, Stuart Price deepens the bass and adds a heavier bass drum. The spoken parts of the vocal are similar to Kylie Minogue's \\"Light Years\\", but the choral vocal is much more immediate. A great song as is for clubs, but could also be a radio hit if it were tightened up a bit.<br /><br />PUSH - This one feels more urban than the rest of the album because of Madonna's staccato vocal delivery. It's sassy and quite catchy.<br /><br />With at least six single-worthy songs and others that have great club rhythms, I recommend this album to any dance or pop music fans. The continuous mix makes skipping songs unnecessary (there are at most two skip-worthy songs on the album), and appreciators of good music production should love how well this continuous effect was done.se!)    SORRY - Rumored to be single #2. A great song which, following the more straightforward Hung Up and Get Together, has a frantic pace in comparison. Reminiscient of her \\"Till Death Do Us Part,\\" but without the unhappy subject matter. This one is all fun, energy, and sass.     HOW HIGH - Has that slight postpunk/pop rhythm, similar to Kylie Minogue's \\"Come into My World.\\" One of the few truly introspective songs on the album, but despite being in a minor (or diminished, I can't quite tell) key, it is not the least bit depressing. It comes across as defiant. Not the sure-bet that Jump and Sorry are, but in an edited length it can be a radio hit.    FUTURE LOVERS - Recreates the bubbling, pulsating bassline from Donna Summer's \\"I Feel Love,\\" however here, Stuart Price deepens the bass and adds a heavier bass drum. The spoken parts of the vocal are similar to Kylie Minogue's \\"Light Years\\", but the choral vocal is much more immediate. A great song as is for clubs, but could also be a radio hit if it were tightened up a bit.    PUSH - This one feels more urban than the rest of the album because of Madonna's staccato vocal delivery. It's sassy and quite catchy.    With at least six single-worthy songs and others that have great club rhythms, I recommend this album to any dance or pop music fans. The continuous mix makes skipping songs unnecessary (there are at most two skip-worthy songs on the album), and appreciators of good music production should love how well this continuous effect was done.

052594527X|5.0|Tracy Chevalier's most famous novel is about the intriguing Vermeer painting of the title. Chevalier gives her an identity- she is of the lower working class, a maid in the household of Johaness Vermeer. Through her eyes, we see the striking world of the Dutch Delft and the varying societies of arists, craftsmen, domestics and nobility. Through language that is not excessively florid, Chevalier describes scenes that are as precise and realistic as Vermeer's paintings themselves. Griet, a quiet but wise young girl, becomes the object of Vermeer's interest, though it is far from sexual. His jealous wife, who births children every year it seems, becomes increasingly jealous of the pretty Griet and the long hours she spends with Vermeer. The decadent, lusty old nobleman, a patron of Vermeer lusts after Griet and is reduced to the dirty old man villain type. The jealous wife too is another stock character. The master and servant relationship is also a bit outdated. While much of this can succumb to good old fashioned historical melodrama, it's really well-written and engaging.

B000BJS4SU|3.0|Before I give my review - I must state the premise that I am a huge John Mayer fan.  I think his first 3 solo albums were near perfectly crafted Pop albums, with Rock and Blues and sometimes Funk and Jazz sensibilities. I however would like to use songs like 3x5, Back to You, Great Indoors, Come Back to Bed, Homelife, Only Heart, and Love Soon as examples of Mayers song writing prowless.  I would like to reference his live shows at college campuses from coast to coast as his solo performances. <br /> <br />When I refer to solo John Mayer I am referring to the above mentioned Mayer.....not Grammy nominee John Mayer.  SO now we have TRY !!!! - From Track 1 (Who Do You Think I Was) - wow what a metaphor - from Track 1 the Trio is Trying too hard -trying so hard to be the musicians's musicians.  I could tell this album was going to be very predictable from the onset.  First 3 Tracks can be one long jam track if they wanted it to be. <br /> <br />Gravity - this is one of the few times Mayer returns to form - so much so that anyone familiar with his solo career think they are getting an impromptu version of Come Back to Bed with this song. <br /> <br />Vultures - another song very reminiscent of Mayer prior to the Trio. <br /> <br />We drudge on through the album - ofcourse Mayer covers \\"I Got a Woman\\"  -been hanging out with Kanye recently huh John.   <br /> <br />The highlight of the album is Something's Missing - for one Mayer is not impersonating himself with the slurred delivery - he is actually enunciating the lyrics - secondly the crowd is actually into this song - and honestly he is just rocking this song. <br /><br />Daughters - Mayer has admitted on several occasions that he would not have chosen this song as a single off of Heavier Things, although he was appreciative of the Grammy nod it got.  So why is he rolling out once again? Come Back to Bed - an electic Love Soon, even a stripped down New Deep would've been much better choices for the Trio to cover. <br /> <br />There is no doubt an evident musical talent throughout this album - Steve Jordan is the drummer, what else can you say.  However, its just not fun to listen to.  Mayer is obviously extremely talented - but he did not move away from the hook of Pop music, he did away with it all together on this album. <br /> <br />I understand why this album was released as a Live effort - as it was easy to put the tracks together and get it out.  But Mayer's voice has fallen apart lately - he is almost a characture of himself with the raspy slur on every song - this could be because of the intricate guitar playing, but nonetheless its not fun to listen to.  Mayer has said that the Trio is able to cut studio tracks in one take - well you should've done that John - because this album falls short - only a couple times did I feel the emotion of the performance. <br /> <br />Reference 3x5 off the Any Given Thursday album to find Mayer at his live best.  Musicians will find tons of reasons to enjoy this album - but the Fan who wants to sing along, will feel lost.

B00000J2SQ|4.0|Straight Between The Eyes came out in 1982 and contains Rainbow's biggest hit, Stone Cold, a \\"power ballad\\" I have never gotten tired of hearing. This was Joe Lynn Turner's second album after the decent Difficult To Cure. The production is better and so are the songs. Highlights are the rockin Death Alley Driver (good chorus and solo), Tearin' Out My Heart (a ballad with great vocals), Power (upbeat rocker), Eyes Of Fire (mystical), and Stone Cold. Every Rainbow album including the last one, Stranger In Us All, has at least a few gems. If I had to choose the best three I would say Rainbow Rising, Straight Between The Eyes, and Bent Out Of Shape. B000063DHL|4.0|Somewhere In Time came between what I consider to be the two best albums in the Iron Maiden catalog.  On this one, they use synthesizers for the first time, and for the most part it works.  Whereas the synthesizers became more a part of the main structure of the music on Seventh Son, on this album they're used mostly for texture. <br /> <br />Strip away the electronics, and you're left with good ol' fashioned Maiden:  Steve's propulsive, in-your-face bass, Dave and Adrian's guitars either in harmony or trading solos, Bruce's soaring voice and Nicko's drumming.  The band shared writing duties on this one more equitably than they did on past albums, although there's not a single writing credit for Bruce. <br /> <br />As for the songs, my favorites are the first two, \\"Caught Somewhere In Time\\" and \\"Wasted Years\\".  Pretty much all the material here is good, but I have to take a couple points off \\"Alexander The Great\\"; the music is terrific, but the lyrics read like an encyclopedia entry.

B000BM6AVA|5.0|This album is the second half of the Mezmerize/Hypnotize album. (recorded at the same time just released several months later) I felt this was a good move because the CD's are quite different thematically and it takes awhile for the music to \\"sink\\" in rather than be bombarded with too much at once.  <br /> <br />The cd itself is an excellent addition to System's repretoire. Since I've been following them since the start, and I've seen a rather drastic evolution within the band. Musically, they have remained relatively the same throughout their albums. We get the same mix of hard metal/rock and slow/melodic songs to complement them. The lyrics, have however, changed for the better. There is more meaning and depth to them than there ever has been (especially with Hypnotize) In my opinion, this is the first System of a Down cd with a central theme, something I enjoy very much while listening to music. <br /> <br />Darron's (guitarist/song writer) role in singing had been rather reserved on the first three albums (SOAD,Toxicity,Steal this Album) but played an equal role as Serj (main singer) on Mezmerize. It worked on some levels, but I prefer Serj as a singer, he seems to have better range and performance. With this second half, Darron's voice is much less heard and only comes in when it is appropriate rather than what seemed to be pushed too much in Mezmerize. As far as the songs go, (these are only my interpretations) <br /> <br />1. Attack: Very hard and fast track, dealing with the loss of human identity and importance to the machines and government. It refers to the breaking point of mankind being reached and stresses the importance of togetherness in times of crisis. <br /> <br />2. Dreaming: This is another heavy \\"traditional\\" System song that , thematically, is almost a continuation of Attack and it mentions the fact that as one mankind cannot accomplish anything it is only by working together. It takes a state of altered consciousness (Dream) and makes it seemthat even in that state, the horrors of life still exist. Quite the pessimistic song. <br /> <br />3. Kill Rock 'N Roll: This song has kind of a Spanish feel to it and works really well within this album. It reminds me of Cigaro off of Mezmerize. It's essentially a song apoligizing for \\"killing rock and roll\\"-as in squandering freedom and all it represents. It also sends the message to enjoy life to its fullest \\"Eat all the grass that you want\\" because \\"accidents\\" can happen at any time <br /> <br />4. Hypnotize: This title track is quite a different approach to a System of a Down song. It's basically a monologue. It refers sarcastically to the rebellions at Tiananmen Square and deals, again sarcastically, with sweatshop labor as \\"the reason they were there\\" <br /> <br />5. Stealing Society: Quite a fast, upbeat intro that quickly turns into a grisly tale of civil war. Not in the traditional sense, though, it's more of a civil war of humanity versus humanity not say certain ethnicities within one nation. Referring to the ones fighting as the Suns and Skies, something we all share, and the overall pointlessness.  <br /> <br />6. Tentative: All System albums have one song with a really awesome riff in them, and this seems to be the song for this album. (War?, X, Question!) This is a continuation of the theme stating that not even God will be able to save us from this downward spiral that we have built. It asks \\"where do you expect us to go when the bombs fall\\" discussing the civilian issues of warfare <br /> <br />7. U-Fig: This is another excellent song, very innovative. A real variety of riffs and types of singing. It is about violent nationalists. (Probably the Americans and the suicide bombers equally) It sarcastically says how important it is to come to the sky and come join the cause but also refers to the pathetic flag waving ignorant pigs so is a very unbiased opinion. (Americans) <br /> <br />8. Holy Mountains: This song is indescribably good. If you don't buy this album, at least download this song from Itunes or something. It is a hypnotic (fittingly) unique System song that mixes chanting with hard riffs and metal. It speaks about a simple minded leader who leads the people and decides what is right and wrong with one word. (Words the people must follow) It also Refers to the \\"River Aras\\", which is a 600 mile long river bordering Armenia. It is implying this is the safe place to go and where we are free. It stresses the stupidity of borders within nations and that we should ideally all be one. <br /> <br />9. Viscinity of Obscenity: This is the traditional \\"nonsense\\" song (On the surface) on this System Cd <br />(Jet Pilot, Sugar, IEAIAIO, TCMMFLIOTS) and it is a very good song with a good beat and interesting instrumentals dealing with how people thrive off those less fortunate and look down on them.  <br />(Think of how you treat fast food employees, for example) <br /> <br />10. She's like Heroin: This is a song referring to people as commodities that cannot be accepted unless they take a traditional role in society. (It deals with the intolerant nature of most people) <br /> <br />11. Lonely Day: This is a slow song sung mostly by Darron and it deals with humanity wanting to bottle up its problems rather than expose them and attempt to get help. However, it does offer hope in that, \\"this time\\" he survived. It teaches us not to keep our emotions to ourself and to share them with someone else to prevent this from happening  <br /> <br />The period of transition is very well done between song 11/12 as it is the same sound between Soldier Side Intro and BYOB off the first cd, kicking it off however this moves into a slower song, <br /> <br />12. Soldier Side: Unlike the intro, this one is done with both singers in harmony. It is a slow, hard song. It is an extremely powerful song referring to God as \\"wearing black\\". A symbol of absolute good has seemingly given up. It also talks about the fact that the manipulativenature of humans inevitably leads to pain and suffering. The ideals of Christianity seem to be gone and \\"never coming back\\" It then breaks and leads into the part of the Soldier side intro \\"welcome to the soldier side...where there's no one here but me...People all grow up to die.\\" except it is sung by both and it is a bit harder. It is an excellent ending to an excellent album. <br /> <br />This album presents an optimistic beginning, representing the \\"potential\\" of mankind but quickly dives into a darker reality except for a few key lines throughout some of the songs that counteract the solid pessimism. It ends up being the ideals that humans need to stay as one will never be accomplished as people are concerned only with their self interest. It even goes as far to say that God Himself has given up. <br /> <br />I highly reccomend this album despite its dark outlook. A better description would be a REAL outlook, not one that has been sugar coated to suit our happy needs. In all senses, this is a masterpiece

They may have showed signs of it in the past but now they have finally crossed the rubicon. Musical maturity is pretty much innevitable if your a band with listening to. Unfortunately, though the songs are all strong for the most part, the band seems to have lost some of whatever made them \\"fun\\" back in 1994 when they gained millions of new fans. <br /> <br />I also don't care what anyone says, I think Green Day were a punk band. Yes, I said it. But however much punk they may have been, they have lost it here. It's not a bad thing, I'm just saying. Naturally some of the songs still have punk overtones in both musical and lyrical content but they are more of just a straight up rock band now. And again, that's not a BAD thing its just different for them. This is a concept album meaning it has a continuous thread linking all of the songs together to a story line very much in the vein of the Who's \\"Tommy\\" (which Billie has pretty much cited as one of his inspirations). <br /> <br />With songs like \\"American Idiot\\" and \\"She's A Rebel\\", Green Day prove they can still write short, catchy pop punk songs. However, with songs like \\"Jesus Of Suburbia\\" (which is a 9 minute rock opera, undoubetdly one of the bands greatest achievements) and even \\"Give Me Novocain\\", they prove they are not afraid to branch out and try new things. My favorite is probably \\"Letterbomb\\". Great song. <br /> <br />This is Green Day's most ambitious album to date and I think in the future we might see them achieving legendary status. In my mind, their already there. If your a new, casual, orold Green Day fan...you can't really go wrong with this album. Although, sometimes when listening to this album its easy to long for tunes in the vein of \\"Basket Case\\" or \\"Nice Guys Finish Last\\".

B000005RT8|5.0|\\"McCartney II\\" was recorded in 1980 right after Paul disbanded Wings. Like his first solo album, \\"McCartney II\\" is another stripped down, at home, McCartney-only production, \\"McCartney II\\" finds Paul in a rather experimental-possibly drug-induced-state. McCartney explores synth-pop here a year before it blew up in the pop-market. Taking a cue from artists like Kraftwerk, Devo and Brian Eno, \\"McCartney II\\" has everything from New Wave spaz-outs (\\"Temporary Secretary\\"), ambient/folk ballads (\\"Waterfalls\\") and paranoid techno ditties (\\"Darkroom\\"). Plus, there is funky and ebullient pop (\\"Coming Up\\"). Sadly, \\"McCartney II\\" marked the end of the Wings era in the same manner \\"McCartney\\" marked the end of The Beatles era. But also like \\"McCartney\\", \\"McCartney II\\" is a charmingly oddball album. And even though he was following the path of techno pioneers, McCartney managed, through his raw production and mixing of real instruments, to create an album that's far less dated than other, colder techno albums from the time-period. It often sounds like the low-fi electronica from 1990s indi-rock acts. Early Stereolab springs to mind. Like two other unsung gems, \\"Wild Life\\" and \\"Back to the Egg\\", \\"McCartney II\\" was snarled at by the critics. However, there was one cat who praised it in 1980: John Lennon. He even cited the \\"Coming Up\\" single as inspiring him out of retirement and to record what would be his final album, \\"Double Fantasy\\" (a FAR more conservative recording than \\"McCartney II\\"). Overall, \\"McCartney II\\" is a great album for those who like funky, witty, homespun, experimental pop-music with a rock & roll edge. Those interested in the album should definitely get the import CD with extra tracks. Especially for the extra track \\"Secret Friend\\": an atmospheric ambient/trance song. It's such a beautiful piece of music and really shows McCartney's stylistic range.
B00005JO17|5.0|My kids and I LOVED chicken little. It had us laughing through the whole movie. Very Cute. I recommend this one as a family movie.
B00005JOHI|5.0|I saw an advanced screening of this film in Boston and was very pleased, it is intelligent in its handle of the material and its fluency in cinematic crafting. Goodbye to dusty, \\"precious\\" interpretations of Jane Austen. This cheeky, poetic, even dark new film makes the story youthful with down-to-earth vibrancy and worship of emotion. Here are young people making the mistakes and dreaming the dreams of the young (when it was written it wasn't antiquity, it was life). Lizzie is not a smirking omniscient but a quick witted independent; hotheaded and fiercely loyal to her sister. She is wary of an unfair world and uses her wits to survive. Darcy is not an impenetrable stoic but a shy sensitive soul with high unwieldy social pretensions fending off the outside world. And they are both lonely and have big yearning hearts, so the filmmakers made one great decision -- they let them fall in love the first moment they lock eyes. In a shot we see hearts behind fortified personalities and an instant chemistry that takes a movie's worth of battling with each other and themselves to right itself. It's an earthy move that sets the tone for a film about the people and world behind the antiquated manners, a world not so different from ours.    Now set in 1797, when Austen wrote the first draft of the book, the filmmakers committed to main plot points and themes, and astutely represent the Romantic Age and Austen's characters.  The love between Jane and Lizzie is supreme and fuels a desire in Lizzie to tear at Darcy when he separates Jane from Mr. Bingley. She's hurt, she reciprocates the pain, and it is bitter.  Pride and prejudices are drawn clearly: Lizzie searches hard to find fault with Darcy, and Darcy cannot bring himself to let down his guard. Both have their reasons justified, but they foil their own chances at love constantly until they see how wrong they are and are too heartsick to keep going. Class conflict is suddenly personally injurious and vicious. When Charlotte Lucas marries for security, it's a grave matter and she must bitingly sober up a disdainful Lizzie on the realities of their world. The Bennets are too eccentric and improper for their own good. Lady Catherine (Dame Judi Dench, who is downright fearsome) is not just a cold figure for Lizzie to spar with, but someone capable of deeply hurting others. The filmmakers are savvy in their understanding of history. Setting it back 20 years is a remarkable move, because we accept more diversions and variation with the 18th century than the 19th and it presents Austen as a Romantic, which automatically requires the story to be interpreted from a different, very legitimate, perspective. The ideals of the Romantic Age are ingeniously, subtly played here: human equality, gritty realism married with beauty for the sake of beauty, but a beauty which is never elitist or decadent, always grounded, simple, and universal: nature, the human being, emotion.    The ensemble and mis-en-scene are electric. The camera spryly edges in and out of rooms and conversations instead of sitting arthritically in a corner. The dance scenes are less about ballet, now rollicking and spirited as characters send signals, flirt, deflect and analyze one another. In true Romantic form (worthy of filling Wordsworth with pride) the aesthetic unabashedly revels in beauty, but always the simple joys of our world: sunrises, dewy landscapes in wide shots, colors everywhere. It has a lovely score, period inspired and without any pomp and circumastance. Simple blocking is caffeinated and given substance, something is always going on in the background. Lively, layered interactions between characters make rich scenes, neither wasting space nor time. Consider a scene with Mr. Collins, played by the magnificent Tom Hollander (a standout here, so delightfully weird. When he jaggedly squirms his way up to someone you want to shriek). He wants to speak to Lizzie, alone, and a bolt of fear strikes through her as she pleadsin vain not to be abandoned. The sisters are merciless, Mrs. Bennet delighted, Mr. Bennet at a loss, and Collins prepares. It's all silent and it's hysterical.     Suggesting variation to revered characters is a frightful task, but here it's a revelation. The entire cast is brilliant, but the two leads are transcendent in their roles. Keira Knightley is charismatic, random, wonderfully young, intuitive to the bone -- she inhabits Lizzie. Matt MacFadyen is deep, remarkably subtle, but mostly he is soulful. I've long held him as a sympathetic actor, but he shines in this.  The two instill an unexpected exuberance of feeling in their performances.  Neither ever acknowledge the camera exists and make the most of every second they have on screen to project their characters. When you throw them together you get a love story full of emotional subtext, double meaning, and gloriously heavy moments.    Because so much dialogue was cut, simple lines have impact and much of the exposition is visual. Epic little moments linger and rain, revealing souls. The thoughts and intentions behind the actors' eyes and words are visible at all times.  This movie understands the power of a shot or glance. Lizzie comes to understand Darcy in how he embraces his sister or smiles (a momentous occasion, indeed). When she talks about love it's stirring because it's finally spilled into the open after we've seen it near the edge many times with half said sentiments and stifled tears. Usually \\"I love you\\" comes with extra explanatory prose, but here sincerity kills clich: parties are fun, a misty field is breathtaking, the dawning of love a revelation, the heartbreak is throbbing.     It's a brilliant film. There is something breathless and luminous about it, from its youth and the break from propriety, to the beauty and spontaneity of life and romance, pain and joy, which provide the color.
B00006JJ51|5.0|This album is a classic and started the gangsta trend you hear today. Definitly recommend all new hip hop heads to buy this
0393317552|4.0|This book is long, detailed and at some points very boring. There is so much information in here that its tough to pass up. You will read on about points the author is trying to make that are dull and insignificant, then you will come to a part that becomes so interesting you wont want to put it down. How the Spaniards conquered Mexico, how the Indians were making the same progress as the Europeans but almost 500 years behind them. How the shape of the continents effected the progress of civilization. How the lack of written word crippled those who had yet to develope it. This will answer your questions on why some parts of the world were able to adapt and develop much faster then others. If you stick with this book till the end you won't regret what you will have learned.

B00009RDGA|5.0|Producer and director Peter Bogdanovich created a visually stunning panorama of sprawling Midwestern landscapes with some marvelous black and white cinematography in his excellent comedic drama \\"Paper Moon\\".  The inseparable tandem of Ryan and Tatum O'Neal were naturals as the scam artist team traveling the backroads of Depression era Kansas.  Nine year old Tatum O'Neal was particularly outstanding in her role as Addie Loggins, paving uncharted waters as the youngest ever recipient of an Academy Award.<br /><br />In a benevolent moment, Ryan O'Neal, playing Moses Pray, a small time con man offered to transport the recently orphaned Addie to her aunt's house in St. Joseph, Missouri.  Along the way Pray discovers that Addie's skills in the con game surpass his own.  They commence successfully working as a team bilking suckers along the way to St. Joe.  They encounter a colorful cast of characters along the way, most notably Madeline Kahn playing dancer/hooker Trixie Delight.  Mose rescues her from a carnival and she begins travelling with them.  She soon begins to compete with Addie for Mose's attention.  In a wittily conceived scene Addie cooks up a scheme to make Mose dump Ms. Delight.<br /><br />Bogdanovich does an exemplary job in capturing the somber and naive mood of Midwestern America in the mid-30's.  He skillfully guides his characters across this landscape, allowing them to create minor mayhem along the way.

B000002U9Y|4.0|Saucerful Of Secrets, released in 1968, is Pink Floyd second studio album.    The band didn't have an easy time back then - its leader and main songwriter, Syd Barrett, left the band because of his drug addiction. David Gilmour replaced him, but Pink Floyd didn't know what to do - without Barrett setting the band's musical direction, they were kinda lost. This is where Roger Waters shined. He mobilizated the band to work and wrote main part of material for the album.    As the result, We've got Pink Floyd psychodelic masterpiece. This album is slightly different from their debut - atmosphere of the songs is dark, mysterious, and more... mature in compare to their first album. Let There Be More Light is a great heavy psychodelic opener with stellar aura about it; Remember A Day is leftover from Piper At Gates... and is very fine Rick Wright composition, sounding somewhat peaceful, but still giving the thrills... impressive. Set The Controls For The Heart Of The Sun is haunting, dark and mysterious - led by a strong bass riff, with a jamming part in the middle. Waters uses chinese poetry as lyrics to this song. An early Pink Floyd classic.  Corporal Clegg is really wierd. It changes its style to often, and it just doesn't work. I consider this and See-Saw as weakest points of the album.  Saucerful Of Secrets is crazy psychodelia at its best - it starts with haunting, piercing sounds and noises - the atmosphere is growing, growing - suddenly it's silence - then comes the awesome drum beat and Gilmour's guitar cries and Wright hits random notes on his piano. After this crazy jamming comes the most beautiful moment in PF music. The choir at the end makes You feel like You're... somewhere in the space. This is one of the best, and most original songs ever.  Unfortunately, the album slips a bit here - See-Saw, as I mentioned before, is the album lowlight. Really lame thing, it sounds like just a bunch of chords put together. I'm sorry, but I have to admit this song is awful.  We have something nice for the end - Jugband Blues, the last song Syd Barrett recorded for the band, is a funny piece, at first sounds a bit folky, but then goes crazy. This song is not to be taken seriously, it is just a joke. I guess Syd wrote this one while He was high on LSD.    Overall, this is one of Pink Floyd most underrated, but best albums. If You search for some excellent psychodelia, You can find it here.

B00005KB9W|5.0|Marley's studio work has always bugged me a tiny bit. I mean, the two albums of his I've heard (Natty Dread and Rastaman Vibration) are both solid works, but I don't really like how he insists on dragging so many early tracks back into the fray. I also find myself scratching my head whenever he involves Rastafari, seeing that I am not a Rasta.<br /><br />But this live album, it's a whole different story. The setlist isn't really all that creative (Other than Kinky Reggae and Burnin' `n' Lootin', anyway), but that's what's good about it-just a bunch of Bob Marley classics, no more, no less. Trenchtown Rock is one of his early songs. As I mentioned before, I usually don't care for most of them, but this is really an exception! Then there's Lively Up Yourself, which puts a whole lotta enegy into the album. An instantly catchy riff and lyrics about either a) sex, b) partying or c) riots (depend on who you talk to), this is definetly a classic!<br /><br />The second side does a heckuva job in lining up Bob's three best-known songs (in my opinion, anyway). First, we have this album's resident classic, in the form of No Woman No Cry. If the only version of NWNC we had was the Natty Dread take, I'm sure the song would've been forgotten. But this, to use an enormous clich&eacute;, immortalizes it.<br /><br />Another good tune is I Shot the Sheriff, one of the best-known reggae tunes ever composed. Doing away with the funkiness of the original, we instead get a swaggering organ riff and great backup singers. And, of course, there's Get Up Stand Up. This one's sang almost like a rap, only about fifteen years before rap sadly became mainstream. In the meantime, this is a good song.<br /><br />Lastly, we have bonus track Kinky Reggae. A light-hearted romp about sex and ganja, it eventually evolves into a loose jam and an introduction of the band. The song is great, and will stay in your head forever, even if it's been weeks since you've heard it last.

B000002MY3|5.0|When this album was unleashed on the world, nobody - including probably Alanis Morissette herself - could have predicted the meteoric impact it would have on not only the music world, but also popular culture itself.  A new generation of youth was empowered by the words and feelings that Alanis offered, finding her music to be therapeutic, as well as a rallying point.<br /><br />Alanis herself is often (and quite unfairly) labeled as an angry woman, even more than a decade after this masterpiece's release.  While there are aggressive songs on this CD, this record covers a myriad of emotions that each of us has.  Through her music, Alanis challenged us all to rediscover those emotions, and in the process, ourselves.  I don't believe I am overstating Alanis' effort; it's that powerful.  Music is supposed to move people, and Jagged Little Pill struck a chord with an astounding number of people around the world, and rightly so.  Songs like \\"Head Over Feet\\" and the `hidden' gem \\"Your House\\" cover a wide range of feelings, with other songs on the record filling in the blanks, including the anthem \\"You Oughta Know\\".<br /><br />In a music scene that currently caters to ITunes and radio, playing for the big single, Alanis had enough foresight to play not for the single, but for the home run.  Each song on this record is huge, and not one song could be considered filler.  Not because it was full of hits, but because it was full of depth and quality, two elements sorely lacking in the current pop tart and cookie cutter era.  Alanis has created many instances of brilliance since this record, but this is the flashpoint for all of it.  This album is truly more than an album; it is an experience.

A woman was not supposed to think, only to please the men in her life.<br /><br />Jane Austen was many years ahead of her time in portraying the unjust social restraints that women had to endure. B00005JOHI|4.0|I've lost count of how many films have been made of Jane Austen's best-loved book, but this latest release is far from the worst. That dubious honor in my view goes to the 1942 movie that had the characters parading around in what looked like wardrobe rejects from \\"Gone With the Wind\\" and Greer Garson at age 36 trying to convincingly play a 20 year old ingenue. Give me a break.<br /><br />The latest film, directed by Joe Wright, is a fairly faithful retelling of Austen's plot, which almost everybody and his mother is familiar with by now, with gorgeous visuals to hook us squarely into the time and place. The visuals, in fact, are so beautiful to look at that at times they tend to overwhelm the story.<br /><br />For anyone out there -- if there is anyone out there -- who doesn't know the plot, \\"Pride and Prejudice\\" introduces us to the Bennet family who belong to the upper-middle-class landed gentry in late 18th century England. The second daughter, Elizabeth, sharp as a marble and pretty to boot, meets Mr. Darcy, a tall, dark, handsome and single young man with money out the wazoo. It's loathing at first sight. He despises her middle-class connections; she thinks he's a stuck-up snob with an attitude. The rest of the story has them finding out how wrong they are about each other; there are a lot of interesting plot twists and turns, but in the end, of course, almost everybody ends up living happily ever after.<br /><br />Jane Austen told her sister Cassandra that she thought the book was \\"rather too light and bright and sparkling\\" but that is exactly what has endeared it to generations of readers in print and on film. Who doesn't love a good love story? But there is a problem with this version; perhaps, in trying to tell the whole story in two hours, it's told too much and not enough both at once. The second and third versions of \\"Pride and Prejudice\\", on BBC in 1980 and A&E in 1995, were serialized over four to five hours and told the story pretty much as Austen wrote it, especially the BBC version, my personal favorite. Joe Wright's film tries to tell the whole story also but there's too much story for two hours to do it justice. As a result, the film feels compressed in spots. It feels truncated. We don't see nearly enough of Elizabeth's Aunt and Uncle Gardiner, two characters who are central to the book; Bingley's married sister and her husband are left out altogether, and the whole movie has a kind of rushed quality. You won't notice it if you haven't read the book and/or seen the BBC or A&E movies, but you'll notice it a lot if you have.<br /><br />Joe Wright also took some positively unsettling liberties with the Bennets. In Austen's book they are an upper-middle-class family who are the \\"principal inhabitants\\" of the neighborhood. In Wright's film, they look like they've gone to seed. The cows are mooing in the back yard, the pigs are ambling into the premises through the back door, a harried-looking Mrs. Bennet and her daughters are toiling in the kitchen (although in the book Mrs. Bennet indignantly tells the Reverend Mr. Collins that her daughters have nothing to do in the kitchen as the family is perfectly well able to afford a good cook), and a bleary-eyed Mr. Bennet sits in his library looking unwashed, uncombed and unkempt. The whole establishment looks drab and dingy, in need of a good paint job. In the earlier movies Longbourn looks like a fairly prosperous estate; this movie conjures up images of Tobacco Road.<br /><br />Keira Knightley is a delight to watch as Elizabeth Bennet; she's smart, sassy and easy on the eyes. She's as good as Elizabeth Garvie was in the role in the BBC version and she's an improvement over Jennifer Ehle. Belinda Blethlyn is funny and ditzy as Mrs. Bennet, an insufferable airhead whose one goal in life is to marry off her brood. Dame Judi Dench is suitably Gorgon-like as Lady Catherine DeBourgh; it's a shame we don't see enough of her in the film either.<br /><br />The big problem for this reviewer was Matthew McFayden's interpretation of Darcy. For a lot of people who saw the other films, the gold standard for Darcy was Colin Firth, although not for this reviewer; I thought Firth was miscast as Darcy (ducking brickbats from Firth groupies as I type this). Firth was trying to be a very 90's Darcy, sensitive and vulnerable; but his Darcy wasn't Austen's Darcy by a long shot. McFayden plays Darcy as if he were racked with inner torment over his wealth and status; he comes off almost as insecure. If there is one thing Austen's Darcy isn't, it's insecure; he's almost too full of himself to be real until Elizabeth knocks him down a few pegs. McFayden was trying to bring out Darcy's soft side -- he has one, underneath all that starched armor -- but in doing so he underplays Darcy's haughty exterior to the point that we wonder what Elizabeth found so revolting about him in the first place. Something doesn't add up.<br /><br />Taken as a whole, the movie delivers in the time it has to do it in. There is no way to faithfully put \\"Pride and Prejudice\\" on film in only two hours. But the essence of the story is there. It's lovely to watch and nice to listen to. Wright does a creditable job of bring Austen's best-loved book to the screen. I just wish he'd made it into a longer film.<br /><br />Judy LindThe big problem for this reviewer was Matthew McFayden's interpretation of Darcy. For a lot of people who saw the other films, the gold standard for Darcy was Colin Firth, although not for this reviewer; I thought Firth was miscast as Darcy (ducking brickbats from Firth groupies as I type this). Firth was trying to be a very 90's Darcy, sensitive and vulnerable; but his Darcy wasn't Austen's Darcy by a long shot. McFayden plays Darcy as if he were racked with inner torment over his wealth and status; he comes off almost as insecure. If there is one thing Austen's Darcy isn't, it's insecure; he's almost too full of himself to be real until Elizabeth knocks him down a few pegs. McFayden was trying to bring out Darcy's soft side -- he has one, underneath all that starched armor -- but in doing so he underplays Darcy's haughty exterior to the point that we wonder what Elizabeth found so revolting about him in the first place. Something doesn't add up.  <br /> <br />Taken as a whole, the movie delivers in the time it has to do it in. There is no way to faithfully put \\"Pride and Prejudice\\" on film in only two hours. But the essence of the story is there. It's lovely to watch and nice to listen to. Wright does a creditable job of bring Austen's best-loved book to the screen. I just wish he'd made it into a longer film. <br /> <br />Judy Lind <br />
0345457684|5.0|A brilliant first novel; I can't say enough good things about it.<br /><br />If Dashiell Hammett and Raymond Chandler wrote hard science fiction, this is what it might look like.<br /><br />The central conceit of the book--that technology has rendered human beings effectively immortal by enabling constant backups of the brain's contents, allowing a person to be transferred essentially intact into another body--opens up a realm of possibilities that Morgan exploits to the fullest.  It's a murder mystery, or a mystery about a crime that isn't quite a murder, actually...<br /><br />Just buy it, read it, savor it.

Zafron writes beautifully and masterfully intertwines mystery, intrigue, history, romance and a sharp wit to form a truly enjoyable and memorable story. Yet curiously, I finished the novel too quickly for I wanted it to continue.  I have been trying to find a novel of this caliber ever since without luck.  Anxiously I await Zafon's next work.

It is always a persistent Black Celebration, which is not simply to evoke a previous era but to suggest a tenor that embraces beauty and joy, and ugliness and pain in life. <br /> <br />It is always fascinating to read that there seems a majority of DM fans out there that suggest Violator as the work that can never again be approached as their greatest work of all. B00005JOHI|5.0|First off, the casting: Keira Knightley was a good choice for Elizabeth Bennet. She would not have been my first choice after the lovely job by Jennifer Ehle in A&E/BBC's 1995 version, but Keira played the part very well and I believed in her Elizabeth from start to finish! Matthew MacFadyen as Darcy: all I can say is WOW! MacFadyen is a relative unknown (I know him only as the gambling loser Felix Carbury in Trollope's \\"The Way We Live Now\\"): his portrayal was passionate, gritty, determined, loveable, heartfelt and moving: I was completely convinced and fell in love (as other Colin Firth fans will likely do so shortly). Added to these two top-notch choices is some other great talent: Rosamund Pike (Lady Harriet Cumnor in \\"Wives & Daughters\\") as Jane Bennet, Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennet, Brenda Blethyn as Mrs. Bennet, Tom Hollander (Osborne Hamley in \\"Wives & Daughters\\") as Mr. Collins, and Judi Dench as Lady Catherine de Bourg: the only somewhat puzzling choices were Rupert Friend as Mr. Wickham and Simon Woods as Mr. Bingley...they seemed to make Mr. Bingley's character incredibly nave and almost silly in this film (which I must admit, did add some nice comic relief), whereas the 1995 P&P chooses to make him only too apt to believe the best in everyone too easily influenced by others. Mr Wickham was only slightly likeable to me, and was not given enough screen time for us to truly believe why Elizabeth defended him so much to Darcy. The cast was rounded out with Jena Malone as Lydia Bennet, Talulah Riley as Mary Bennet, and Carey Mulligan as Kitty Bennet, as well as a few others.     The overall storyline and feel: I thought they did an excellent job condensing the storyline into a theatrical movie-length version. I was mighty impressed with the screenwriter, and was not surprised to find out that Emma Thompson (who wrote the screenplay for 1995's \\"Sense & Sensibility\\", as well as giving an Oscar-winning performance as Elinor Dashwood) did an un-credited and unpaid rewrite of the new \\"Pride & Prejudice\\" script: she is given a special thanks in the end credits. The cinematography of the film was well done, with gorgeous scenes and imagery created: the soundtrack score is excellent, soft and unassuming, but seems to blend perfectly with the film: highly recommended. There is little that I would like to change overall: a few content issues (as described below), and otherwise, my changes would be: 1) the final scene: it is a bit too modern-feeling, and not true to Jane Austen as it should be 2) one scene where Lizzie reads a letter: she is upset & crying, only I thought it felt a bit stilted and not quite credible 3) Lady Catherine's speech to Elizabeth: I felt it could have been stronger, and have more \\"umph\\" behind it. Set design and costumes: the costumes work perfectly with the mood and feel of the film: at first I was a bit disappointed that they put Elizabeth in so much brown, but it works very well with the grit and feel of the film (and makes it seem much more real), and there are times (like at the Netherfield Ball), when you get some gorgeous white & light-colored costumes on the characters (including a beautiful snow-white dress on Elizabeth, with a lovely upswept hairdo). I thought the set design was very well done, and loved the very realistic feel of the film: the comparison between the Bennet house and Pemberly is quite drastic and added to the credibility of Darcy's wealth.     For those of you interested in \\"family-friendly\\" remarks, read this paragraph, otherwise you can skip to the next one. Content: There is one scene with a character walking through a room full of white, marble statues, mostly nude, and admiring them: mostly the shots show behinds, though some naked breasts are shown as well in a ceiling painting. There is one use of a*s, and little else in the way of language. There is some dialogue that alludes to the fact that an unmarried man & woman ran off together, not necessarily with any plans to get married, but it is eventually resolved; there is some cleavage shown, but nothing too drastic. All in all, the content is kept to a minimum.     This beautifully-filmed and well-acted movie is well worth the time & effort of going to the movie theatre, in a day and age when there is often little that does such. The romance they created in a few scenes was, I felt, beyond compare. For those of you who loved & enjoyed A&E and BBC's 1995 version of \\"Pride & Prejudice\\" with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle, you are in for a treat: there are enough differences in the movies to make them both loveable, but enough similarities in dialogue that you don't feel you are missing anything. This new film & soundtrack is highly recommended (I bought the soundtrack from Amazon UK a month ago, as it is being released Nov 15th in the USA): this movie will also end up being a must-add to any woman's DVD collection!!

B0002234LS|5.0|Secret Window is a gut-wrenching horror tale that is meant to be watched just as it is seen through the eyes of Mort Rainey--thoroughly alone and thoroughly frightened. Which is where the frightening aspect comes from, and is exactly how I watched it.  <br /> <br />From the opening sequence of Secret Window I was enthralled. The slightly off-kelter look the Depp always possesses drew me in, with the even more slightly insane look in his eyes, staring at me through the window of the car. After a few moments I hear a voice: <br /> <br />\\"Do not go back.\\" <br /> <br />This is the moment where all movie watchers should stop and think about whether they want to go ahead, and let themselves have the crap scared out of them. Turn it off, and wonder exactly why he was not supposed to go back, or continue, and go through the Secret Window that is Mort's mind. <br /> <br />After this point move six months forward, and now Mort is the burnt out novelist; he's facing a case of writer's block the size of Mt. Everest, an ugly divorce, and the loss of his baby. He lives in a cabin in the middle of nowhere'sville New York, and has this crazy southerner hounding him about a story that he claims Mort stole from him--what's not to like about this setting? <br /> <br />Soon enough tension levels start to rise, and you begin to get little ideas in your head. Is Ted trying to push him into signing the divorce papers? Is Shooter just crazy? Did Mort really steal the story? <br /> <br />The movie is moving along with the force of a subway train when we finally get to the trainwreck--a riveting scene in which Mort has to face Shooter, and all of his demons come out. The climactic scene is truly that--climactic and chaotic, as we are forced to choose between his almost-innocent wife and Mort, who we have been pulling for all along.  <br /> <br />Hitting Ted in the face with the shovel was hillarious, the end scene with the corn haunting as Mort chants: <br /> <br />\\"All that matters is the ending,\\" he says, pausing for effect, \\"and this one... this one is perfect.\\" And let me tell you folks, once you go through the Secret Window... there is no coming out.
0142000655|5.0|After the slaying of his brother, the biblical Cain dwelt in the land \\"east of Eden,\\" protected from the wrath of men by the divine mark placed upon him but vulnerable to his own sense of guilt and its consequence, a forlorn and hateful existence.  Does Cain still have the choice of salvation through self-determination or is he foredoomed to damnation?<br /><br />The answer to this question is crucial to the characters in Steinbeck's novel, where parallels to Cain and his brother, Abel, are abundant.  Predestination or self-determination?  Both philosophies come to bear on the characters in this story.  We see the unrelenting descent into sin and depravity by the child Catherine as her cold and calculating acts become ever more heinous and she devolves from the girl Cathy into the woman Kate, the madam of a house of sadism.  At the end, Kate frightens herself into suicide, which, by the way, is one of Steinbeck's powerful ironies inasmuch as the person whom Kate fears is, unbeknownst to her, already dead.<br /><br />Of all the persons whom we meet in this novel, Kate alone seems to have no hope of salvation, and this hardly seems fair for she alone seems to have had no choice. She alone appears predestined to damnation.  She alone feels no remorse, no guilt, indeed nothing at all. She alone is utterly cold and empty of human emotion.  She is preternaturally evil, and she seems to have been born thus.  Is she, then, the counterpart of the biblical Eve, whose act of disobedience was so unforgivably heinous that not only she but all of her progeny were driven from the Garden of Eden into a dark, painful world and made to suffer for her Original Sin for as long as mankind shall exist?  (We must accept Christian mythology here for sake of discussion.)<br /><br />As the biblical Eve was the consort of the biblical Adam, and the dam of Cain and Abel, so Kate begets Caleb and Aron, who are raised as the sons of her husband, Adam Trask. The fact that Adam's brother Charles was the biological father adds even more to the ponderous weight of sin that courses through the novel.  Can the generations ever be freed of spiritual darkness?  The answer lies in Timshel, the Hebrew verb meaning, according to the Oriental servant and philosopher Lee, \\"thou mayest,\\" a translation different from that commonly accepted in the King James Version of the Bible.<br /><br />Lee suggests that God continues to give man a choice, free will to work toward repentance and salvation or toward sin and damnation.  \\"Thou mayest\\" follow the course that thou will.  Caleb, even though he feels that he is mean and ugly and that his actions led to Aron's death, hence making him a murderer as surely as Cain was a murderer, may nevertheless prove to be the turning point and achieve salvation.  If he manages this, it will be through the influence and aid of Abra, and her presence in the story saves Steinbeck from being labeled a misogynist, to which his portrayal of Kate would surely have led.  Still, the turning point lies in the future beyond the end of the novel, and Steinbeck does not tell us whether or not Cal succeeds.  Abra's name inevitably reminds me of that of Abraham, too; are she and Cal destined to be the founders of future \\"saved\\" generations?<br /><br />These are only a few of the major themes that weave through this work. We could also explore the fatal flaw shared by Adam and his son Aron, their failure to see reality and their insistence of living in a world that is as insubstantial as their nave dreams.  Thus do they contribute to their own destruction.  We could examine more of the ironies of life that permeate this novel, as they do all of Steinbeck's creations. Suffice it to say that EAST OF EDEN is full of both interest and meaning, for it speaks to the essential question of mankind's spiritual salvation, a question that has resulted in tremendous schisms among theologians, and it speaks to this question through a constantly evolving plot that captures the reader's interest immediately and pulls him through the novel without pity!<br /><br />This book probably belongs on the \\"must-read\\" list of American novels, and I commend it and its message to every literate adult (and precocious teenager) who possesses the will and the courage to examine the most basic of human choices and who is willing to decide for himself how to translate \\"Timshel.\\" However, there is a prerequisite reading assignment. Before starting EAST OF EDEN, do read at least Chapters 3 and 4 from the Book of Genesis. They're short, but without some knowledge of them, the reader will miss the point that Steinbeck so intriguingly makes.t that captures the reader's interest immediately and pulls him through the novel without pity! <br /> <br />This book probably belongs on the \\"must-read\\" list of American novels, and I commend it and its message to every literate adult (and precocious teenager) who possesses the will and the courage to examine the most basic of human choices and who is willing to decide for himself how to translate \\"Timshel.\\" However, there is a prerequisite reading assignment. Before starting EAST OF EDEN, do read at least Chapters 3 and 4 from the Book of Genesis. They're short, but without some knowledge of them, the reader will miss the point that Steinbeck so intriguingly makes.

B000BM6AVA|4.0|Rather than review each portion of this album separately (Mesmerize/Hypnotize), I've decided to review the collection as one whole. First, I find it amusing that when \\"Mesmerize\\" came out 6 months ago, everyone thought that it was great. Fast forward to now and the response seems partially luke warm with some being outright negative towards \\"Hypnotize\\". I think had this second part to the overall album just been released as a double album, everyone would have loved it. Perhaps the band made a miscue by dividing the releases apart from one another? Or perhaps System Of A Down has hit the beginning of their popularity downslide. This seems to be the case with any artist: once they hit their popularity peak, there's nowhere to go but down. Granted, U2 has seemingly defied those odds by consistently releasing bad albums that the public herald as \\"classic\\" but for the rest of the bands on Earth, it's all a game of how long they can stay atop the wave before they get sucked into the current.<br /><br />I'll put it this way: \\"Toxicity\\" was truly a landmark album for this band. It not only made System Of A Down a household name but beyond the hype, it is an album of truly great songs. They established themselves an identity and broke far and away from the term nu-metal all in one fell swoop. Naturally, this album will likely always be their benchmark with most people and though it's not their most creative album by any stretch, the strength of the songs solidified it as a truly classic album. With \\"Mesmerize/Hypnotize\\", you might be able to scrape together a similar amount of strong songs between the two as you got with \\"Toxicity\\" by itself. From my perspective, System Of A Down has grown creatively and musically since \\"Toxicity\\" and the level of experimentation is obvious but in the end, they may have sacrificed the opportunity to \\"strike while the iron is hot\\" in terms of having songs the world will love.<br /><br />To that, I say who cares what the world wants. The world's (namely America) music audience has a very short attention span and it always will. Though I think System Of A Down has hit a weird period in their career, I think the combination of creativity and songwriting is going to result in their best works in the future. Unfortunately, with some people seemingly already jumping ship, who knows how many people will still be around to enjoy it.orld's (namely America) music audience has a very short attention span and it always will. Overall, the songs I can tolerate are Burn it Down, In Loving Memory, Down to My Last, Watch Your Words, and Shed My Skin.

B000BISBDY|5.0|What people say about leaders is also true about Johnny Cash fans: They aren't born, they're made. <br /> <br />As a child of the 80s--a time when \\"Karma Chameleon\\" was considered the height of musical sophistication--I never knew much about Johnny Cash. I just knew him as The Man in Black, a vaguely famous country singer. Then I saw Walk the Line, bought The Legend of Johnny Cash CD, and was converted. Cash has IT. He has that something that makes the listener stop and connect with the song. <br /> <br />So, as a new fan, it's a difficult if not impossible task to pick the \\"best\\" songs on this career-spanning album. All the older hits are there--\\"Cry Cry Cry,\\" \\"I Walk the Line,\\" \\"Get Rhythm,\\" \\"Ring of Fire\\"--and haven't lost their original luster. (\\"I Walk the Line\\" is my personal favorite from this era because the lyrics cut straight into the soul of anyone who's ever been cynical, lonely, and completely surprised by love.) \\"Jackson\\" is a firecracker-hot duet with June Carter, but \\"It Ain't Me, Babe\\" is conspicuously absent. <br /> <br />His more contemporary works--\\"Delia's Gone,\\" for instance--also stand out as testaments to the timelessness of his rolling bass line and world-weary voice. Cash's covers, too, are brilliant. His rendition of Hank Snow's \\"I've Been Everywhere\\" is appealing, as is his take on Soundgarden's \\"Rusty Cage.\\" <br /> <br />But, for me, the number one song on the album is \\"Hurt,\\" Cash's interpretation of Nine Inch Nails' paen to addiction. His quavering vocals bely the universality of the pain of addiction, and the slowly-building background music makes the reader understand the increasing desperation of dependency. The song wraps you up in its raw emotion and nearly overwhelms you. For a second, you know what it means to be an addict, to give anything--\\"my empire of dirt\\"--to change. For a second, Cash sets up shop in your soul. <br /> <br />After hearing \\"Hurt,\\" I knew why so many people love Cash. While his voice may quiver, it has a dramatic urgency that burns the songs into your brain. That voice is the sound of redemption from a man who's been to the bottom and barely made it back up. <br /> <br />Bottom line: This is an excellent introduction to The Man in Black. It's a small slice of his talent, but it's sure to leave you wanting more.
